column1: **Summary and Action Items:**
* Measles is spreading across the United States and this health alert serves to update current recommendations.

* Report suspect measles cases to CDPH immediatelyat**312-743-9000** (or 311 and ask to speak to the communicable disease physician on call) to initiate timely confirmation of diagnosis with measles RT-PCR.
* There is no recommendation for an adult catch-up program for persons born before 1989.
* Vaccination recommendations may change over time depending on local activity but current vaccination efforts in
Chicago should focus on routine, on-time vaccination of children (tips provided below) and high-risk infants and adults.

**For Measles questions or to report Cases contact CDPH at 312-743-9000**. For questions during non-business hours call 311. (312-744-5000 if outside the City of Chicago.) Suspect Cases should be reported within 24 Hours. Do not wait for laboratory confirmation.
Go to [www.chicagohan.org/measles](https://www.chicagohan.org/measles) for additional information on reporting suspect measles cases to Chicago Department of Public Health.
Please see the attachment for more information.",True,
CDC is Looking for Healthcare Providers to Share Feedback,2019-05-02T16:18:08.000,46655280,STI,,Low,CDC is Looking for Healthcare Providers to Share Feedback!,"
column2: Do You Use CDC’s STD Treatment Guidelines Mobile App?  CDC is Looking for Healthcare Providers to Share Feedback!
column4: If you are a healthcare provider (doctor, nurse, PA) providing clinical care to patients who have an STD or are at risk for STDs and you have used the CDC STD Tx Guide app in the past 12 months, CDC wants to hear from you!
column6: In anticipation of the next iteration of CDC’s STD Treatment Guidelines, CDC is working to update the popular STD Tx Guide app. The STD Tx Guide app is an easy-to-use, free mobile app for healthcare providers that allows users to access CDC’s current STD Treatment Guidelines from their mobile device. The app provides critical information needed for the diagnosis and treatment of 21 STDs and sexual assault, access to the full STD Treatment Guidelines, and access to “A Guide to Taking a Sexual History”.
column8: Please contact KB Xiong at vyf1@cdc.gov or (404) 498-6476 to schedule a quick 30-minute interview.  Your feedback is vital to help the CDC improve the next version of the app!","Do You Use CDC's STD Treatment Guidelines Mobile App? CDC is Looking for Healthcare Providers to Share Feedback!

column1: If you are a healthcare provider (doctor, nurse, PA) providing clinical care to patients who have an STD or are at risk for STDs and you have used the CDC STD Tx Guide app in the past 12 months, CDC wants to hear from you!

In anticipation of the next iteration of CDC's STD Treatment Guidelines, CDC is working to update the popular STD Tx Guide app. The STD Tx Guide app is an easy-to-use, free mobile app for healthcare providers that allows users to access CDC's current STD Treatment Guidelines from their mobile device. The app provides critical information needed for the diagnosis and treatment of 21 STDs and sexual assault, access to the full STD Treatment Guidelines, and access to ""A Guide to Taking a Sexual History"".

Please contact KB Xiong at [vyf1@cdc.gov](mailto:vyf1@cdc.gov) or (404) 498-6476 to schedule a quick 30-minute interview. Your feedback is vital to help the CDC improve the next version of the app!",False,

IDPH Memo: Call for Elizabethkingia spp. Laboratory Reports and Isolates,2019-04-25T14:43:38.000,46654785,Infectious Disease,,Low,Call for Elizabethkingia spp. Laboratory Reports and Isolates,"<div>
column2: <div>
column4: Elizabethkingia is a genus of bacteria commonly found in the environment. Although it rarely makes people sick, it has been associated with cases among immunocompromised individuals. Additionally, outbreaks in Illinois health care settings have been reported. Elizabethkingia infections are often multidrug resistant and associated with high mortality.
column5: <div>
column10: The Cook County Department of Public Health and the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) have been investigating two separate clusters of Elizabethkingia anophelis in long-term care facilities located in Cook County. To identify cases associated with the Cook County clusters and to better understand the genetic diversity of Elizabethkingia spp. infections in Illinois, we are requesting:
column14: <div>
column16: 1) any laboratory reports of Elizabethkingia spp. infections and
column22: 2) any available Elizabethkingia spp. isolates. Available isolates will be submitted to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for additional laboratory identification to include whole genome sequencing.
column26: <div>
column28: Specifically, laboratories that serve residents of Cook (including Chicago), Lake, McHenry, Kane, Will, and DuPage counties are requested to send:
column34: - Reports of any Elizabethkingia species (e.g., meningoseptica, anophelis) isolated from blood/serum or respiratory source from January 1, 2017 to present
column40: - Reports should include if possible: Patient name, date of birth, date of specimen collection, specimen type, and facility from where the specimen was collected.
column46: - Reports can be securely faxed to IDPH at 312-338-0390 or securely emailed to DPH.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov
column52: - If any Elizabethkingia isolates are available in your laboratory, please email IDPH at DPH.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov to arrange for transport to the CDC for additional testing.
column58: IDPH will compile data from submitted laboratory reports and will share Elizabethkingia spp. reports with the local health department where the patient was located at the time of specimen collection. Additional case information may be need to help characterize infection risk factors, and IDPH will provide guidance regarding this data collection to relevant local health departments.
column64: Questions regarding this call for cases can be directed to IDPH at DPH.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov
column66: ","Elizabethkingia is a genus of bacteria commonly found in the environment. Although it rarely makes people sick, it has been associated with cases among immunocompromised individuals. Additionally, outbreaks in Illinois health care settings have been reported. Elizabethkingia infections are often multidrug resistant and associated with high mortality.

column1: The Cook County Department of Public Health and the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) have been investigating two separate clusters of Elizabethkingia anophelis in long-term care facilities located in Cook County. To identify cases associated with the Cook County clusters and to better understand the genetic diversity of Elizabethkingia spp. infections in Illinois, we are requesting:
1) any laboratory reports of Elizabethkingia spp. infections and

2) any available Elizabethkingia spp. isolates. Available isolates will be submitted to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for additional laboratory identification to include whole genome sequencing.
Specifically, laboratories that serve residents of Cook (including Chicago), Lake, McHenry, Kane, Will, and DuPage counties are requested to send:
- Reports of any Elizabethkingia species (e.g., meningoseptica, anophelis) isolated from blood/serum or respiratory source from January 1, 2017 to present
- Reports should include if possible: Patient name, date of birth, date of specimen collection, specimen type, and facility from where the specimen was collected.
- Reports can be securely faxed to IDPH at 312-338-0390 or securely emailed to DPH.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov
- If any Elizabethkingia isolates are available in your laboratory, please email IDPH at DPH.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov to arrange for transport to the CDC for additional testing.

IDPH will compile data from submitted laboratory reports and will share Elizabethkingia spp. reports with the local health department where the patient was located at the time of specimen collection. Additional case information may be need to help characterize infection risk factors, and IDPH will provide guidance regarding this data collection to relevant local health departments.
Questions regarding this call for cases can be directed to IDPH at DPH.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov",True,

NEW REGISTRATION INSTRUCTIONS:
* Registration in Eventbrite is now closed. For all new registrations, please register via the Health Alert Network (<https://bit.ly/2G1OlvM>).
* You do not need to register via the Health Alert Network if you already registered in Eventbrite.
* Each attendee should register for only one meeting and changes should be emailed to ChicagoVFC@cityofchicago.org. In the event of duplicate registration, only the latest registration will be valid.
* Each attendee must use a unique email address, please do not use an email address shared by your clinic. Attendees must register prior to the meeting.
* Please email Chicagovfc@cityofchicago.org with any questions.
**2019 Chicago VFC Program Re-enrollment**

VFC Re-Enrollment forms were due Monday, April 15th. In order to continue being a part of the VFC program and receiving no-cost vaccine for your clinic, fill out the 2019 re-enrollment form in I-CARE and fax in a signed provider agreement to 312-746-6220. Don't hesitate to email [chicagovfc@cityofchicago.org](mailto:chicagovfc@cityofchicago.org) with any questions.",False,

IDPH Health Advisory:  Control and Containment of Candida auris (C.auris),2019-04-17T21:03:06.000,46654778,Infectious Disease,,Low,IDPH Health Advisory:  Control and Containment of Candida auris (C.auris),"<div>
column2: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) is circulating a Health Advisory to update health care partners in the control and containment of Candida auris (C.auris).  The document contains new updates on the following: cases counts, new disinfection agents, laboratory submission guidance
column4: Chicago providers and laboratories may contact the Chicago Department of Public Health at cdphhaiar@cityofchicago.org  or Massimo Pacilli – Laboratory Liaison at 312-746-6225 or Massimo.pacilli@cityofchicago.org  for:
column5: <ul>
column10: Reporting within 7 days identification of confirmed Candida auris, or Candida species commonly misidentified based on yeast identification methods
column15: Guidance on C. auris screening of potentially exposed contacts
column20: Guidance on patient cohorting (i.e., grouping patients infected with the same infectious agents together to confine their care to one area and prevent contact with susceptible patients)
column22: <li>
column25: Guidance on infection control interventions
column29: The Health Advisory is attached to this email.
column32:
More information regarding C. auris is availible at https://www.chicagohan.org/cauris.

","The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) is circulating a Health Advisory to update health care partners in the control and containment of Candida auris (C.auris). The document contains new updates on the following: cases counts, new disinfection agents, laboratory submission guidance

column1: Chicago providers and laboratories may contact the Chicago Department of Public Health at [cdphhaiar@cityofchicago.org](mailto:cdphhaiar@cityofchicago.org) or Massimo Pacilli -- Laboratory Liaison at 312-746-6225 or [Massimo.pacilli@cityofchicago.org](mailto:Massimo.pacilli@cityofchicago.org) for:

* Reporting within 7 days identification of confirmed Candida auris, or Candida species commonly misidentified based on [yeast identification methods](https://www.cdc.gov/fungal/candida-auris/recommendations.html)
* Guidance on C. auris screening of potentially exposed contacts
* Guidance on patient cohorting (i.e., grouping patients infected with the same infectious agents together to confine their care to one area and prevent contact with susceptible patients)
* Guidance on infection control interventions
The Health Advisory is attached to this email.
More information regarding C. auris is availible at <https://www.chicagohan.org/cauris>.",True,
Weekly Chicago Flu Update Week 14,2019-04-16T15:04:27.000,46654777,Influenza,,Low,Weekly Flu Update Week 14,"<div>
column2: The Chicago Flu Update for Week 14 has been published. As long as influenza viruses are circulating and unexpired vaccine is available, influenza vaccinations should continue to be offered. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago Walk-In Immunization Clinics available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to www.chicagoflushots.org
column5: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is decreasing.
column9: For the week of March 31-April 6, 2019, 13 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.
column10: <div>
column15: Since September 30, 2018, 313 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; 298 were positive for influenza A (125 H1N1pdm09, 14 H3N2, and 159 unknown subtype [subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested]) and 15 were positive for influenza B. The median age of reported cases is 59 years (range 1 month-92 years); one pediatric death was reported and 17 cases were admitted from long-term care facilities
column16: <div>
column21: Data on influenza virus test results are reported by Chicago laboratories performing influenza RT-PCR. For the week of March 31-April 6, 2019, 253 of the 1,287 (19.7%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 234 typed as influenza A (31 H1N1pdm09, 45 H3N2, and 158 unknown subtype) and 19 typed as influenza B.
column23: The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
column24: Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.
column25:
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza.

","The Chicago Flu Update for Week 14 has been published. As long as influenza viruses are circulating and unexpired vaccine is available, influenza vaccinations should continue to be offered. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago [Walk-In Immunization Clinics](https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/immunizations_walk-inclinics.html) available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](https://chicagoflushots.org/)

column1: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is decreasing.
For the week of March 31-April 6, 2019, 13 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, 313 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; 298 were positive for influenza A (125 H1N1pdm09, 14 H3N2, and 159 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and 15 were positive for influenza B. The median age of reported cases is 59 years (range 1 month-92 years); one pediatric death was reported and 17 cases were admitted from long-term care facilities

Data on influenza virus test results are reported by Chicago laboratories performing influenza RT-PCR. For the week of March 31-April 6, 2019, 253 of the 1,287 (19.7%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 234 typed as influenza A (31 H1N1pdm09, 45 H3N2, and 158 unknown subtype) and 19 typed as influenza B.
The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,

Potential for Measles Spread during Passover amid Domestic and International Measles Outbreaks,2019-04-12T22:23:31.000,46654580,Vaccine Preventable,,Low,Potential for Measles Spread during Upcoming Passover Holiday amid Domestic and International Measles Outbreaks,"<div>
column2: <div>
column7: Potential for Measles Spread during Upcoming Passover Holiday amid Domestic and International Measles Outbreaks
column15: The following activities have been shown to limit the spread of measles in healthcare facilities:
column24: Symptom-based patient triage and early identification of clinical presentations consistent with measles.
column27: <li>
column31: Early initiation of isolation precautions (details in attachment).
column38: Immediate reporting of suspect measles cases to CDPH at 312-743-9000 (or 311 and ask to speak to the communicable disease physician on call) to initiate timely confirmation of diagnosis with measles RT-PCR.
column45: Leveraging your electronic medical record to adopt measles testing order sets, perform recall of high-risk patients who are not up to date on MMR vaccination, and to support active measles surveillance.
column52: Reviewing employee evidence of measles immunity now and taking appropriate actions.
column68: For Measles questions or to report Cases contact CDPH at 312-743-9000.  For questions during non-business hours call 311. (312-744-5000 if outside the City of Chicago.)  Suspect Cases should be reported within 24 Hours.  Do not wait for laboratory confirmation.
column82: Go to www.chicagohan.org/measles for additional information on reporting suspect measles cases to Chicago Department of Public Health.
column89: Please see the attachment for more information. ","**Potential for Measles Spread during Upcoming Passover Holiday amid Domestic and International Measles Outbreaks**

column1: **Summary and Action Items:**
The following activities have been shown to limit the spread of measles in healthcare facilities:
* Symptom-based patient triage and early identification of clinical presentations consistent with measles.
* Early initiation of isolation precautions (details in attachment).

* **Immediate reporting of suspect measles cases to CDPH at 312-743-9000**(or 311 and ask to speak to the communicable disease physician on call) to initiate timely confirmation of diagnosis with measles RT-PCR.

* Leveraging your electronic medical record to adopt measles testing order sets, perform recall of high-risk patients who are not up to date on MMR vaccination, and to support active measles surveillance.
* Reviewing employee evidence of measles immunity now and taking appropriate actions.

**For Measles questions or to report Cases contact CDPH at 312-743-9000**. For questions during non-business hours call 311. (312-744-5000 if outside the City of Chicago.) Suspect Cases should be reported within 24 Hours. Do not wait for laboratory confirmation.
Go to [www.chicagohan.org/measles](https://www.chicagohan.org/measles) for additional information on reporting suspect measles cases to Chicago Department of Public Health.
Please see the attachment for more information.",True,

IDPH Laboratory Memo: Packaging and Shipping: Division 6.2 Materials Seminar,2019-04-09T21:13:31.000,46654487,Laboratory Information,,Low,IDPH Laboratory Memo: Packaging and Shipping: Division 6.2 Materials Seminar,"
column2: Packaging and Shipping: Division 6.2 Materials Seminar sponsored by Sponsored by Illinois Department of Public Health, Division of Laboratories and the Association of Public Health Laboratories
column4: The following IDPH Laboratory Memo entitled "APHL Packaging and Shipping Flyer" is attached to this notification.
column6: The Illinois Department of Public Health, Division of Laboratories and the Association of Public Health Laboratories is sponsoring a packaging and shipping seminar. This intermediate-level, one-day program provides a comprehensive overview of regulations applicable to packaging and shipping laboratory specimens. Lectures, demonstrations, and group exercises will be used to provide instruction on complying with international, federal, and local transportation regulations.
column8: Participants will be tested on their knowledge of the regulations and receive documentation of attendance and testing. Participants will meet Department of Transportation (DOT) training requirements upon satisfactory course completion and documentation of Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) blood borne pathogen or other safety training and security training.
column10:
This program is designed for laboratorians who package, ship, and transport Division 6.2 hazardous materials such as patient specimens, cultures, and dry ice. Please see the attached brochure for specific times and dates. If you have specific questions related to this packaging and shipping seminar, please contact Robert Cox at : robert.f.cox@illinois.gov

","Packaging and Shipping: Division 6.2 Materials Seminar sponsored by Sponsored by Illinois Department of Public Health, Division of Laboratories and the Association of Public Health Laboratories

column1: The following IDPH Laboratory Memo entitled ""**APHL Packaging and Shipping Flyer** "" is attached to this notification.

The Illinois Department of Public Health, Division of Laboratories and the Association of Public Health Laboratories is sponsoring a packaging and shipping seminar. This intermediate-level, one-day program provides a comprehensive overview of regulations applicable to packaging and shipping laboratory specimens. Lectures, demonstrations, and group exercises will be used to provide instruction on complying with international, federal, and local transportation regulations.

Participants will be tested on their knowledge of the regulations and receive documentation of attendance and testing. Participants will meet Department of Transportation (DOT) training requirements upon satisfactory course completion and documentation of Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) blood borne pathogen or other safety training and security training.

This program is designed for laboratorians who package, ship, and transport Division 6.2 hazardous materials such as patient specimens, cultures, and dry ice. Please see the attached brochure for specific times and dates. If you have specific questions related to this packaging and shipping seminar, please contact Robert Cox at : [robert.f.cox@illinois.gov](mailto:robert.f.cox@illinois.gov)",True,

Psychological First Aid Training Opportunity,2019-04-08T14:43:13.000,46654481,Announcement,,Low,Psychological First Aid Training Opportunity,"
column2: Chicago Department of Public Health Emergency Preparedness Program No cost Training in Psychological First Aid: Basic Principles
column3: If you are a provider and want to learn how to support people experiencing a disaster, Psychological First Aid (PFA) provides you with effective ways to help survivors manage their distress and needs. Psychological First Aid is a nonclinical intervention and formal healthcare training is not required.
column4: Participants will learn to:
column5: provide survivors with early psychosocial support during a disaster.
column6: use PFA intervention strategies to prevent further harm and help survivors cope.
column7: support provider care before, during, and after disaster care.
column8: Training Date:  May 16th 2019.  The session meets from 9:00 am to 3:00 pm. Lunch is on your own, noon to 1 pm.
column9: CDPH Training Center 1642 N. Besly Court, Chicago. Free off street parking.
column10:
To register, choose a session and send to nikoleta.boukydis@cityofchicago.org.

","**Chicago Department of Public Health Emergency Preparedness Program No cost Training in Psychological First Aid: Basic Principles**

column1: **If you are a provider and want to learn how to support people experiencing a disaster, Psychological First Aid (PFA) provides you with effective ways to help survivors manage their distress and needs. Psychological First Aid is a nonclinical intervention and formal healthcare training is not required.**
**Participants will learn to:**
**provide survivors with early psychosocial support during a disaster.
use PFA intervention strategies to prevent further harm and help survivors cope.
support provider care before, during, and after disaster care.
Training Date: May 16th 2019. The session meets from 9:00 am to 3:00 pm. Lunch is on your own, noon to 1 pm.**
**CDPH Training Center 1642 N. Besly Court, Chicago. Free off street parking.**
**To register, choose a session and send to** [**nikoleta.boukydis@cityofchicago.org**](mailto:nikoleta.boukydis@cityofchicago.org).",False,

IDPH Health Alert: New Measles Case In Cook County,2019-03-29T20:26:53.000,46654479,Vaccine Preventable,,Low,IDPH Health Alert: New Measles Case In Cook County,"<div>
column2: <div>
column4: A measles case has been diagnosed in a Cook County adult who travelled internationally.  There are two known exposure locations in Chicago.  CDPH is contacting known exposures in Chicago residents directly.
column5: <div>
column10: Providers should screen patients with clinically compatible illness for the exposure settings contained in the atatched  SIREN alert.
column14: Due to elevated state and national measles activity, providers should ensure that all patients, including those travelling internationally or to any area with an ongoing outbreak, are up to date on MMR vaccine.
column16: Visit https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html for an up to date listing of ongoing US measles outbreaks and https://www.cdc.gov/measles/travelers.html for traveler notices to endemic areas internationally.
column18: <div>
column20: For Measles questions or to report Cases contact CDPH at 312-743-9000.  For questions during non-business hours call 311. (312-744-5000 if outside the City of Chicago.)  Suspect Cases should be reported within 24 Hours.  Do not wait for laboratory confirmation.
column24: Go to www.chicagohan.org/measles for additional information on reporting suspect measles cases to Chicago Department of Public Health.
column26: Please see the attachment for more information.","A measles case has been diagnosed in a Cook County adult who travelled internationally. There are two known exposure locations in Chicago. CDPH is contacting known exposures in Chicago residents directly.

column1: Providers should screen patients with clinically compatible illness for the exposure settings contained in the atatched SIREN alert.

Due to elevated state and national measles activity, providers should ensure that all patients, including those travelling internationally or to any area with an ongoing outbreak, are up to date on MMR vaccine.

Visit <https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html> for an up to date listing of ongoing US measles outbreaks and <https://www.cdc.gov/measles/travelers.html> for traveler notices to endemic areas internationally.

**For Measles questions or to report Cases contact CDPH at 312-743-9000**. For questions during non-business hours call 311. (312-744-5000 if outside the City of Chicago.) Suspect Cases should be reported within 24 Hours. Do not wait for laboratory confirmation.
Go to [www.chicagohan.org/measles](https://www.chicagohan.org/measles) for additional information on reporting suspect measles cases to Chicago Department of Public Health.
Please see the attachment for more information.",True,

column1: **SUMMARY AND ACTION ITEMS**
**PROVIDERS:**
* Chicago has identified 4 outbreak-associated HAV cases in the past month.

* Have a low threshold to report clinical suspicion for hepatitis A in high risk individuals (those with unstable housing, homelessness, drug-users, or men who have sex with men) to Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH).
* Vaccinate high risk individuals for hepatitis A now.
**LABORATORIES:** Save all reactive hepatitis A IgM specimens for 30 days.",True,

Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago [Walk-In Immunization Clinics](https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/immunizations_walk-inclinics.html) is available on the city website and by calling 311. column1: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is high.
For the week of March 10 - March 16, 2019, 24 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, 244 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; 235 were positive for influenza A (102 H1N1pdm09, 8 H3N2, and 125 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and nine were positive for influenza B. The median age of reported cases is 58 years (range 1 month-92 years); one pediatric death was reported and 14 cases were admitted from long-term care facilities.

Data on influenza virus test results are reported by Chicago laboratories performing influenza RT-PCR. For the week of March 10-16, 2019, 264 of the 1,360 (19.4%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 252 typed as influenza A (69 H1N1pdm09, 27 H3N2, and 156 unknown subtype) and 12 typed as influenza B.
The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,

Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago [Walk-In Immunization Clinics](https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/immunizations_walk-inclinics.html) is available on the city website and by calling 311. column1: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is high.
For the week of February 24 - March 2, 2019, eight influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, 180 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; 172 were positive for influenza A (77 H1N1pdm09, 3 H3N2, and 92 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and eight were positive for influenza B. The median age of reported cases is 57 years (range 1 month-92 years); one pediatric death was reported and nine cases were admitted from long-term care facilities.

Data on influenza virus test results are reported by Chicago laboratories performing influenza RT-PCR. For the week of February 24-March 2, 2019, 162 of the 1,011 (16.0%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 154 typed as influenza A (32 H1N1pdm09, 12 H3N2, and 110 unknown subtype) and eight typed as influenza B.

For the week of February 24-March 2, 2019, 102 of the 5,513 (1.8%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is lower than Illinois (3.2%), Region 5 (3.4%) and the U.S. (4.7%).
The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,
Salmonella Infantis Outbreak,  March 2019,2019-03-07T20:16:44.000,46653880,Bacterial,,Low,Salmonella Infantis Outbreak - March 2019,"<div>
column2: Key Messages and Action Steps
column6: Perform stool culture for symptomatic (diarrhea, fever, abdominal cramps) patients who consumed foods purchased at the Supermercado Rivera grocery store (4334 W. 51st St., Chicago, IL, 60632), or for patients with febrile diarrheal symptoms, even if they report no exposure to the establishment.
column9: Report any confirmed cases of salmonellosis promptly to the Chicago Department of Public Health Communicable Disease Program at 312-743-9000 during normal business hours (M-F, 8:30 AM - 4:30 PM). If an exposure to the establishment is identified outside of regular business hours, dial 3-1-1 to report to the communicable disease physician on call.
column12: Backgound: As of March 6, 2019, CDPH has identified 5 confirmed cases of salmonellosis who reported eating carnitas or other foods purchased on February 23, 2019 or February 24, 2019 from the Supermercado Rivera deli counter (4334 W. 51st St., Chicago, IL, 60632). Several other reports of clinically compatible illness among those eating foods from the grocery store on the same two dates have also been received, though not yet confirmed by laboratory testing. Four cases have tested positive for Salmonella serogroup Infantis with matching PFGE pattern; the serogroup results for one confirmed case are pending. Symptom onset dates range from February 23, 2019 to February 26, 2019; we expect more cases to present for medical care. On 3/1/19, CDPH performed an environmental assessment of the grocery store and provided guidance on safe food handling practices and environmental cleaning to prevent further spread of disease. Implicated food items were no longer available at the store as of Mar 1, 2019 and there was no evidence that food made after this date was contaminated. CDPH is monitoring closely for additional reports of illness. It is critical that healthcare providers test patients with symptoms consistent with salmonellosis and promptly report positive results to the health department.
column14: Symptoms: Salmonellosis symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps, which usually present between 12 and 72 hours after exposure. Diarrhea onset is often sudden, and nausea and vomiting may accompany illness. Symptoms typically resolve within four to seven days but can occasionally last longer. Although most cases are self-resolving, treatment may be indiciated in the elderly, infants, and those with impaired immune systems who are at increased risk of invasive disease. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that Salmonella causes approximately one million illnesses and 450 deaths in the United States each year.
column16: Laboratory evaluation and treatment: Patients presenting with diarrhea and a compatible illness should have a stool culture for Salmonella. For 2 cases in which susceptibility report was available, the strain was susceptible to ampicillin, ciprofloxacin, and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.  Treatment guidelines for Salmonella may be found at https://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/general/technical.html. Salmonella isolates should be sent to the Illinois Department of Public Health laboratories. Stool cultures are critical to confirm the organism and to complete pulsed field gel electrophoresis testing, which is necessary to link outbreak cases together.
column18: Reporting: Salmonella infections are reportable to the Chicago Department of Public Health. To report a suspected or confirmed Salmonella infection or for questions regarding communicable disease reporting, call the CDPH reporting line at 312-743-9000 during normal business hours (M-F, 8:30 AM - 4:30 PM).  If calling outside of normal business hours, dial 3-1-1 to contact the on-call medical personnel, or if you are calling from outside of Chicago, dial 312-744-5000.","**Key Messages and Action Steps**

column1: * **Perform stool culture for symptomatic (diarrhea, fever, abdominal cramps) patients who consumed foods purchased at the Supermercado Rivera grocery store (4334 W. 51st St., Chicago, IL, 60632), or for patients with febrile diarrheal symptoms, even if they report no exposure to the establishment.**

* **Report any confirmed cases of salmonellosis promptly to the Chicago Department of Public Health Communicable Disease Program at 312-743-9000 during normal business hours (M-F, 8:30 AM - 4:30 PM). If an exposure to the establishment is identified outside of regular business hours, dial 3-1-1 to report to the communicable disease physician on call.**

**Backgound**: As of March 6, 2019, CDPH has identified 5 confirmed cases of salmonellosis who reported eating carnitas or other foods purchased on February 23, 2019 or February 24, 2019 from the Supermercado Rivera deli counter (4334 W. 51st St., Chicago, IL, 60632). Several other reports of clinically compatible illness among those eating foods from the grocery store on the same two dates have also been received, though not yet confirmed by laboratory testing. Four cases have tested positive for Salmonella serogroup Infantis with matching PFGE pattern; the serogroup results for one confirmed case are pending. Symptom onset dates range from February 23, 2019 to February 26, 2019; we expect more cases to present for medical care. On 3/1/19, CDPH performed an environmental assessment of the grocery store and provided guidance on safe food handling practices and environmental cleaning to prevent further spread of disease. Implicated food items were no longer available at the store as of Mar 1, 2019 and there was no evidence that food made after this date was contaminated. CDPH is monitoring closely for additional reports of illness. It is critical that healthcare providers test patients with symptoms consistent with salmonellosis and promptly report positive results to the health department.

**Symptoms:** Salmonellosis symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps, which usually present between 12 and 72 hours after exposure. Diarrhea onset is often sudden, and nausea and vomiting may accompany illness. Symptoms typically resolve within four to seven days but can occasionally last longer. Although most cases are self-resolving, treatment may be indiciated in the elderly, infants, and those with impaired immune systems who are at increased risk of invasive disease. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that Salmonella causes approximately one million illnesses and 450 deaths in the United States each year.

**Laboratory evaluation and treatment** : Patients presenting with diarrhea and a compatible illness should have a stool culture for Salmonella. For 2 cases in which susceptibility report was available, the strain was susceptible to ampicillin, ciprofloxacin, and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. Treatment guidelines for Salmonella may be found at <https://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/general/technical.html>. Salmonella isolates should be sent to the Illinois Department of Public Health laboratories. Stool cultures are critical to confirm the organism and to complete pulsed field gel electrophoresis testing, which is necessary to link outbreak cases together.

**Reporting**: Salmonella infections are reportable to the Chicago Department of Public Health. To report a suspected or confirmed Salmonella infection or for questions regarding communicable disease reporting, call the CDPH reporting line at 312-743-9000 during normal business hours (M-F, 8:30 AM - 4:30 PM). If calling outside of normal business hours, dial 3-1-1 to contact the on-call medical personnel, or if you are calling from outside of Chicago, dial 312-744-5000.",True,

The median age of reported cases is 57 years (range 1 month-92 years); one pediatric death was reported and eight cases were admitted from long-term care facilities.

Data on influenza virus test results are reported by Chicago laboratories performing influenza RT-PCR. For the week of February 17-23, 2019, with 5 laboratories reporting, 158 of the 993 (15.9%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 153 typed as influenza A (40 H1N1pdm09, 5 H3N2, and 100 unknown subtype) and five typed as influenza B.

For the week of January February 17-23, 2019, 117 of the 5,619 (2.1%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is lower than Illinois (3.2%), Region 5 (3.0%) and the U.S. (5.0%)
The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,

column2: Warning about Stem Cell Therapies
column6: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) are warning patients and providers about the risks of procedures involving unproven and unapproved stem cell therapies.
column9: Currently, the only stem cell treatments approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are products that treat certain cancers and disorders of the blood and immune system. If the products are being used for arthritis, injury-related pain, chronic joint pain, anti-aging or other health issues, they are not approved by FDA unless they are part of a study under an Investigational New Drug Application (IND).
column10: <li>
column12: As a result of bacterial infections in patients following the use of stem cell products from the ReGen Series® (distributed by Liveyon, LLC), an FDA investigation into the manufacturer, Genetech, revealed inappropriate screening of stem cell donors for diseases such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus.
column15: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) is unaware of bacterial infections occurring in Illinois residents following the use of cells from the ReGen Series®; however, patients who received these cells since 2017 are advised to discuss evaluation for HIV, hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, and possibly other blood-borne infections with their healthcare providers (see diagnosis section below).
column16: <li>
column18: The Chicago Department of Public Health will be notifying known Chicago clinics that used the ReGen Series®. These clinics will be asked to notify patients that received these products from 2017 to the present. Patients will be advised to speak with a health care provider regarding the need for testing for HIV, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus and, in some circumstances, other pathogens (see diagnosis section above).  If patients do not have a health care provider or are unable to afford testing, they should contact Chicago Department of Public Health:
column19: Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information.

","**Warning about Stem Cell Therapies**

column1: **Summary and Action Items**
1. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) are warning patients and providers about the risks of procedures involving unproven and unapproved stem cell therapies.

2. Currently, the only stem cell treatments approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) are products that treat certain cancers and disorders of the blood and immune system. If the products are being used for arthritis, injury-related pain, chronic joint pain, anti-aging or other health issues, they are not approved by FDA unless they are part of a study under an Investigational New Drug Application (IND).

3. As a result of bacterial infections in patients following the use of stem cell products from the ReGen Series® (distributed by Liveyon, LLC), an FDA investigation into the manufacturer, Genetech, revealed inappropriate screening of stem cell donors for diseases such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus.

4. The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) is unaware of bacterial infections occurring in Illinois residents following the use of cells from the ReGen Series®; however, patients who received these cells since 2017 are advised to discuss evaluation for HIV, hepatitis B virus, hepatitis C virus, and possibly other blood-borne infections with their healthcare providers (see diagnosis section below).

5. The Chicago Department of Public Health will be notifying known Chicago clinics that used the ReGen Series®. These clinics will be asked to notify patients that received these products from 2017 to the present. Patients will be advised to speak with a health care provider regarding the need for testing for HIV, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus and, in some circumstances, other pathogens (see diagnosis section above). If patients do not have a health care provider or are unable to afford testing, they should contact Chicago Department of Public Health:
Please email [CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org](mailto:CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org) or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information.
Please see the attachment for more information.",True,

Corrected: Increased Pertussis Activity in North Side Chicago Childcare Settings,2019-02-27T16:42:30.000,46653678,Bacterial,,Low,Corrected: Increased Pertussis Activity in North Side Chicago Childcare Settings Strengthened Prophylaxis and Vaccination Recommendations,"<div>
column2: Updated with correct attachment
column5: <li>
column7: Due to increased local activity in a cluster of childcare facilities, CDPH is strengthening post- exposure prophylaxis and vaccination recommendations for all families reporting exposure to pertussis in these settings.
column10: Healthcare providers may see an increase in the number of patients seeking evaluation, testing, prophylaxis, or treatment for pertussis due to ongoing exposures and outbreaks at Chicago area childcare centers located in Lincoln Park, Lakeview, North Center, Albany Park, Irving Park,  and Logan Square.
column13: Providers should ask about recent exposure in patients presenting with cough for over 14 days. Pertussis vaccination history should not alter plans to test or prescribe post-exposure prophylaxis.
column16: From October 1, 2018 to February 25, 2019, Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) received reports of 62 pediatric pertussis cases; 22 (35%) under 12 months old; 30 (48%) involved 14 daycares. This increased from 26 pediatric cases during the same time period last year in which 7 (27%) were under 12 months old and 2 (8%) involved 2 daycares. The childcare settings are mostly clustered on the north side of the city necessitating management of a significant number of exposures to prevent a larger outbreak. In periods of baseline pertussis activity, public health recommendations in group settings can vary depending on the number of cases identified, age of index case, and duration of cough.  Persons with pertussis are infectious from the beginning of the catarrhal stage (runny nose, sneezing, low-grade fever) through the third week after the onset of paroxysms (multiple, rapid coughs) or until 5 days after the start of effective antimicrobial treatment.
column18: Outbreak Guidance to Prevent Further Pertussis Transmission:
column19: In isolated childcare outbreaks of 5 or more cases (lower threshold if infant cases), CDPH recommends exposed children seek medical evaluation to receive either prophylaxis (if asymptomatic) or testing with treatment/prophylaxis (if symptomatic) and return to the childcare facility ONLY when treatment is completed or prophylaxis is initiated.
column23: Due to increased local activity in a cluster of childcare facilities, CDPH is expanding the above recommendation to children with exposure to > 1 pertussis case in a daycare setting.
column25: Families and employees may present with letters from certain childcare facilities and these facilities are being instructed to reserve the right to exclude children or staff if they refuse evaluation/management and then become symptomatic. Families will be asked to provide some evidence of either phone/in-office triage by a healthcare provider in the form of an antibiotic prescription, after-visit summary, or note. Factors to consider when determining if phone triage is appropriate include age of the patient exposed, underlying medical conditions, and provider relationship with family.
column27: Please see the attached HAN for more information.","*Updated with correct attachment*

column1: **SUMMARY AND ACTION ITEMS**

* **Due to increased local activity in a cluster of childcare facilities, CDPH is strengthening post- exposure prophylaxis and vaccination recommendations for all families reporting exposure to pertussis in these settings.**

* **Healthcare providers may see an increase in the number of patients seeking evaluation, testing, prophylaxis, or treatment for pertussis due to ongoing exposures and outbreaks at Chicago area childcare centers located in Lincoln Park, Lakeview, North Center, Albany Park, Irving Park, and Logan Square.**

* **Providers should ask about recent exposure in patients presenting with cough for over 14 days. Pertussis vaccination history should not alter plans to test or prescribe post-exposure prophylaxis.**
**Background**

From October 1, 2018 to February 25, 2019, Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) received reports of 62 pediatric pertussis cases; 22 (35%) under 12 months old; 30 (48%) involved 14 daycares. This increased from 26 pediatric cases during the same time period last year in which 7 (27%) were under 12 months old and 2 (8%) involved 2 daycares. The childcare settings are mostly clustered on the north side of the city necessitating management of a significant number of exposures to prevent a larger outbreak. In periods of baseline pertussis activity, public health recommendations in group settings can vary depending on the number of cases identified, age of index case, and duration of cough. Persons with pertussis are infectious from the beginning of the catarrhal stage (runny nose, sneezing, low-grade fever) through the third week after the onset of paroxysms (multiple, rapid coughs) or until 5 days after the start of effective antimicrobial treatment.
**Outbreak Guidance to Prevent Further Pertussis Transmission:**

In isolated childcare outbreaks of 5 or more cases (lower threshold if infant cases), CDPH recommends exposed children seek medical evaluation to receive either prophylaxis (if asymptomatic) or testing with treatment/prophylaxis (if symptomatic) and return to the childcare facility ONLY when treatment is completed or prophylaxis is initiated.
* **Due to increased local activity in a cluster of childcare facilities, CDPH is expanding the above recommendation to children with exposure to \> 1 pertussis case in a daycare setting.**

Families and employees may present with letters from certain childcare facilities and these facilities are being instructed to reserve the right to exclude children or staff if they refuse evaluation/management and then become symptomatic. Families will be asked to provide some evidence of either phone/in-office triage by a healthcare provider in the form of an antibiotic prescription, after-visit summary, or note. Factors to consider when determining if phone triage is appropriate include age of the patient exposed, underlying medical conditions, and provider relationship with family.
Please see the attached HAN for more information.",True,

For the week of January February 10-16, 2019, 101 of the 5,296 (1.9%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is lower than Illinois (2.8%), Region 5 (2.5%) and the U.S. (5.1%)

IDPH Health Alert: Measles immunity among Health Care workers,2019-02-22T20:46:04.000,46653381,Vaccine Preventable,,Low,IDPH Health Alert: Measles immunity among Health Care workers,"<div>
column2: Recommendations and Action Items:
column4: 1.) Healthcare providers should have documented evidence of measles immunity
column5: 2.) Healthcare providers without evidence of measles immunity should be offered 2 doses of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine
column6: 3.) Healthcare facilities should have readily available lists of immunity status of all health care personnel
column10: Ongoing measles outbreaks nationwide, including recently confirmed cases in Illinois, provides an opportunity to remind health care facilities and providers of the recommendation that all health care personnel* (HCP) have evidence of immunity to measles.
column12: HCP are at higher risk than the general adult population for becoming infected with measles. If a measles exposure occurs in a facility, it can be costly, and can lead to a substantial disruption of hospital routines, especially if the immunity of staff is unknown. If a measles exposure occurs in a facility, non-immune exposed HCPs are required to be excluded from work from the 5th - 21st day after exposure.
column14: For these and other reasons, ACIP guidelines recommend that all HCP should have presumptive evidence of immunity to measles. Further, facilities should have this documented and readily available.
column16: For HCPs, presumptive evidence of immunity to measles for persons includes any of the following:
column17: • written documentation of vaccination with 2 doses of live measles or MMR vaccine administered at least 28 days apart
column18: • laboratory evidence of immunity (eg- positive measles serum IgG)
column19: • laboratory confirmation of disease, or
column21: **For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles immunity, health-care facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles
column23: For HCPs without presumptive evidence of immunity, pre-vaccination antibody screening before MMR vaccination is not necessary, unless the medical facility considers it cost effective. Serologic testing for immunity is not recommended for HCP who have 2 documented doses of MMR vaccine.
column25: For complete informaiton please see the attachment below.
column27: *HCP’s are defined as all paid and unpaid persons working in health-care settings, which includes (but is not limited to) physicians, nurses, technicians, students / trainees, contractual staff not employed by the health-care facility, and persons (e.g., clerical, housekeeping, volunteers) not directly involved in patient care but potentially exposed to infectious agents.","**Recommendations and Action Items:**

column1: 1.) Healthcare providers should have documented evidence of measles immunity
2.) Healthcare providers without evidence of measles immunity should be offered 2 doses of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine
3.) Healthcare facilities should have readily available lists of immunity status of all health care personnel
**Background:**

Ongoing measles outbreaks nationwide, including recently confirmed cases in Illinois, provides an opportunity to remind health care facilities and providers of the recommendation that all health care personnel\* (HCP) have evidence of immunity to measles.

HCP are at higher risk than the general adult population for becoming infected with measles. If a measles exposure occurs in a facility, it can be costly, and can lead to a substantial disruption of hospital routines, especially if the immunity of staff is unknown. If a measles exposure occurs in a facility, non-immune exposed HCPs are required to be excluded from work from the 5th - 21st day after exposure.
For these and other reasons, ACIP guidelines recommend that all HCP should have presumptive evidence of immunity to measles. Further, facilities should have this documented and readily available.
For HCPs, presumptive evidence of immunity to measles for persons includes any of the following:
• written documentation of vaccination with 2 doses of live measles or MMR vaccine administered at least 28 days apart
• laboratory evidence of immunity (eg- positive measles serum IgG)
• laboratory confirmation of disease, or
• birth before 1957\*\*
*\*\*For unvaccinated personnel born before 1957 who lack laboratory evidence of measles immunity, health-care facilities should recommend 2 doses of MMR vaccine during an outbreak of measles*

For HCPs without presumptive evidence of immunity, pre-vaccination antibody screening before MMR vaccination is not necessary, unless the medical facility considers it cost effective. Serologic testing for immunity is not recommended for HCP who have 2 documented doses of MMR vaccine.
For complete informaiton please see the attachment below.

\*HCP's are defined as all paid and unpaid persons working in health-care settings, which includes (but is not limited to) physicians, nurses, technicians, students / trainees, contractual staff not employed by the health-care facility, and persons (e.g., clerical, housekeeping, volunteers) not directly involved in patient care but potentially exposed to infectious agents.",True,
IDPH Health Alert: Measles Health Alert,2019-02-22T20:16:44.000,46653379,Vaccine Preventable,,Low,IDPH Health Alert: Measles Health Alert,"
column2: A total of four measles cases have now been confirmed in Champaign, IL leading to potential exposures, now including a childcare setting.  Providers should screen patients with clinically compatible illness for the exposure settings contained in the SIREN alert.  Visit www.chicagohan.org/measles for additional information on reporting suspect measles cases to Chicago Department of Public Health.
column5: Summary and Action Items
column6: <div>
column11: 1.) Provide awareness of two additional measles (four total) cases leading to potential exposures in Champaign, Illinois.
column14: 2.) Encourage health care providers to consider measles in the differential of clinically compatible cases, especially with appropriate exposure risks.
column17: 3.) Remind providers to immediately report any suspect cases, at the time of clinical testing, and outline appropriate steps for diagnosis and isolation.
column18: <div>
column20: 4.) Currently, there are no changes to the national recommended MMR vaccine schedule for children in Illinois. Continue to give MMR vaccine at 12-15 months of age, and 4-6 years of age.
column24: <div>
column26: Background
column27: <div>
column32: From January 1 to February 14, 2019, 127 individual cases of measles have been confirmed in ten states (https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html), with many states experiencing outbreaks. In Illinois, four recent cases of measles have been diagnosed in Champaign County. All four measles cases are no longer infectious. Individuals who are known to have been exposed during the contagious period have been directly contacted. However, exposures can also have occurred in public areas, where it is impossible to identify all potential contacts.  A list of locations where cases were known to have been while infectious and should still be considered exposure locations for patients with clinically compatible symptoms is included in the attachment.
column44: When considering whether a clinically compatible case may have been exposed to measles, please ask if the patient might have been exposed at any of the locations listed in the attachment. Patients presenting for measles evaluation should be assessed for potential exposure at these locations on the dates and times listed. A patient may develop symptoms up to 21 days after the exposure date. Unvaccinated person who were exposed at any of these locations should be quarantined for 21 days after their most recent exposure; refer to your local health department for guidance.
column47: ","A total of four measles cases have now been confirmed in Champaign, IL leading to potential exposures, now including a childcare setting. Providers should screen patients with clinically compatible illness for the exposure settings contained in the SIREN alert. Visit [www.chicagohan.org/measles](https://www.chicagohan.org/measles) for additional information on reporting suspect measles cases to Chicago Department of Public Health.

column1: Summary and Action Items
1.) Provide awareness of two additional measles (four total) cases leading to potential exposures in Champaign, Illinois.
2.) Encourage health care providers to consider measles in the differential of clinically compatible cases, especially with appropriate exposure risks.
3.) Remind providers to immediately report any suspect cases, at the time of clinical testing, and outline appropriate steps for diagnosis and isolation.
4.) Currently, there are no changes to the national recommended MMR vaccine schedule for children in Illinois. Continue to give MMR vaccine at 12-15 months of age, and 4-6 years of age.
Background

From January 1 to February 14, 2019, 127 individual cases of measles have been confirmed in ten states (<https://www.cdc.gov/measles/cases-outbreaks.html>), with many states experiencing outbreaks. In Illinois, four recent cases of measles have been diagnosed in Champaign County. All four measles cases are no longer infectious. Individuals who are known to have been exposed during the contagious period have been directly contacted. However, exposures can also have occurred in public areas, where it is impossible to identify all potential contacts. A list of locations where cases were known to have been while infectious and should still be considered exposure locations for patients with clinically compatible symptoms is included in the attachment.
Potential Exposures in Illinois

When considering whether a clinically compatible case may have been exposed to measles, please ask if the patient might have been exposed at any of the locations listed in the attachment. Patients presenting for measles evaluation should be assessed for potential exposure at these locations on the dates and times listed. A patient may develop symptoms up to 21 days after the exposure date. Unvaccinated person who were exposed at any of these locations should be quarantined for 21 days after their most recent exposure; refer to your local health department for guidance.",True,

IDPH Memo: Updated Malaria Testing Guidance for the IDPH Division of Laboratories,2019-02-22T17:20:36.000,46653377,Laboratory Information,,Low,IDPH Memo: Updated Malaria Testing Guidance for the IDPH Division of Laboratories,"<div>
column2: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH), Division of Laboratories, is issuing guidance related to Malaria testing.  Please see the attachment for the entire message.
column4: Effective immediately, the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) Springfield Laboratory will only test EDTA blood specimens using an RT-PCR assay for malaria testing. Microscopic observation will no longer be conducted and slides are no longer acceptable. RT- PCR testing for Malaria has a faster turnaround time and increased sensitivity.
column6: If specimens are being referred to IDPH laboratories which have shown parasitic infection through microscopic observation in the original testing facility and PCR analysis at IDPH is unable to confirm malaria infection, blood can be referred to CDC for supplemental testing to rule-out Babesia.
column8: When submitting specimens, please include any microscopic observation results including semi-quantitation information (such as a low-level of parasitemia), on page two in the “Other Pertinent Information” area of the Communicable Diseases Laboratory Test Requisition form. Please see attached updated Instructions for Malaria Specimen Submission.
column10: If you have any questions about these changes, please do not hesitate to contact our Springfield Laboratory at 217-782-6562.
column17: 1. Use a lavender/purple top vacutainer tube containing EDTA anticoagulant. Collect a minimum of 1.0 mL of blood. Mix specimen(s) by gentle inversion five to 10 times.
column18: 2. Label the specimen tube with the patient’s full name and date of birth.
column19: 3. Complete all information on the Communicable Diseases test requisition. Preliminary microscopic observations including semi-quantitation, such as low-level of parasitemia, etc., should be included on page two in the “Other Pertinent Information” section of the Communicable Diseases Laboratory Test Requisition form.
column20: 5. Messenger/Courier by ground transport: Wrap specimen in absorbent material. Place wrapped specimen into a biohazard labeled bag and seal securely. Place the test requisition on the outside of the biohazard labeled bag. Place the sealed biohazard bag and test requisition inside the shipping container. The shipping container must be rigid such as a cooler and labeled with the UN 3373 Biological Substance Category B marking. Close securely.
column21: 6. Commercial carrier by ground/air transport: Place the specimen inside a biohazard labeled 95 kPa bag and add sufficient absorbent material to absorb the entire contents. Seal following the instructions on the bag. Place the test requisition(s) in the 95 kPa bag outside pouch and seal following the instructions on the bag. Place the sealed 95 kPa bag and completed test requisition(s) inside the shipping container and close securely. Label the outer shipping container with the Illinois Department of Public Health laboratory address. Complete the return address section to include the name of the person shipping the package, business name and address and a business phone number. The shipping container must include the UN 3373 Biological Substance Category B marking.
column22: 7. Prior to shipping, hold the specimens at 4-8°C and then ship the specimen (overnight) in a cooler on a cold pack.

column30: 217-782-6562","The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH), Division of Laboratories, is issuing guidance related to Malaria testing. Please see the attachment for the entire message.

column1: Effective immediately, the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) Springfield Laboratory will only test EDTA blood specimens using an RT-PCR assay for malaria testing. Microscopic observation will no longer be conducted and slides are no longer acceptable. RT- PCR testing for Malaria has a faster turnaround time and increased sensitivity.

If specimens are being referred to IDPH laboratories which have shown parasitic infection through microscopic observation in the original testing facility and PCR analysis at IDPH is unable to confirm malaria infection, blood can be referred to CDC for supplemental testing to rule-out Babesia.

When submitting specimens, please include any microscopic observation results including semi-quantitation information (such as a low-level of parasitemia), on page two in the ""Other Pertinent Information"" area of the Communicable Diseases Laboratory Test Requisition form. Please see attached updated Instructions for Malaria Specimen Submission.
If you have any questions about these changes, please do not hesitate to contact our Springfield Laboratory at 217-782-6562.
Illinois Department of Public Health
Division of Laboratories
Instructions for Malaria Specimen Submission
1. Use a lavender/purple top vacutainer tube containing EDTA anticoagulant. Collect a minimum of 1.0 mL of blood. Mix specimen(s) by gentle inversion five to 10 times.
2. Label the specimen tube with the patient's full name and date of birth.

3. Complete all information on the Communicable Diseases test requisition. Preliminary microscopic observations including semi-quantitation, such as low-level of parasitemia, etc., should be included on page two in the ""Other Pertinent Information"" section of the Communicable Diseases Laboratory Test Requisition form.

5. Messenger/Courier by ground transport: Wrap specimen in absorbent material. Place wrapped specimen into a biohazard labeled bag and seal securely. Place the test requisition on the outside of the biohazard labeled bag. Place the sealed biohazard bag and test requisition inside the shipping container. The shipping container must be rigid such as a cooler and labeled with the UN 3373 Biological Substance Category B marking. Close securely.

6. Commercial carrier by ground/air transport: Place the specimen inside a biohazard labeled 95 kPa bag and add sufficient absorbent material to absorb the entire contents. Seal following the instructions on the bag. Place the test requisition(s) in the 95 kPa bag outside pouch and seal following the instructions on the bag. Place the sealed 95 kPa bag and completed test requisition(s) inside the shipping container and close securely. Label the outer shipping container with the Illinois Department of Public Health laboratory address. Complete the return address section to include the name of the person shipping the package, business name and address and a business phone number. The shipping container must include the UN 3373 Biological Substance Category B marking.
7. Prior to shipping, hold the specimens at 4-8°C and then ship the specimen (overnight) in a cooler on a cold pack.
Ship to:
Illinois Department of Public Health
Division of Laboratories
825 N. Rutledge Street
Springfield, IL 62702
Weekly Chicago Flu Update Week 06,2019-02-15T20:36:38.000,46653179,Influenza,,Low,Weekly Flu Update Week 06,"
column2: The Chicago Flu Update for Week 06 has been published. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago Walk-In Immunization Clinics is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to www.chicagoflushots.org.

column14: For the week of February 3-9, 2019, 26 of 59 (44%) zip codes had ILI activity levels in the moderate to high categories; this is lower than last season where 86% of zip codes were at moderate to high levels for the same time period.

","The Chicago Flu Update for Week 06 has been published. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago [Walk-In Immunization Clinics](https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/immunizations_walk-inclinics.html) is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](https://chicagoflushots.org/).

column1: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is high.
For the week of February 3-9, 2019, 14 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, 124 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; 116 were positive for influenza A (56 H1N1pdm09, 2 H3N2, and 58 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and eight were positive for influenza B.

Several outpatient clinics throughout Chicago participate in CDC's Influenza-like Illness Surveillance Network (ILINet) by reporting on a weekly basis the total number of outpatient clinic visits, and of those visits, the number with influenza-like illness (ILI). For the week of January February 3-9, 2019, 68 of the 5,776 (1.2%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is lower than Illinois (2.4%), Region 5 (2.4%) and the U.S. (4.8%).

For the week of February 3-9, 2019, 26 of 59 (44%) zip codes had ILI activity levels in the moderate to high categories; this is lower than last season where 86% of zip codes were at moderate to high levels for the same time period.
The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,
IDPH Memo: Communicable Disease Rules Changes,2019-02-11T18:42:00.000,46653079,Infectious Disease,,Low,IDPH Memo: Communicable Disease Rules Changes,"
column2: Amendments to the IDPH Communicable Disease Code (Rules and Regulations for Communicable Disease Control and Immunizations - 77 Illinois Administrative Code 690) were adopted on Friday,February 8, 2019. The primary change was the repeal of all or part of six diseases or conditions.
column3: Following is a summary of the changes for the diseases reportable to IDPH’s Communicable Disease Section.
column4: Following is a summary of the changes for the diseases reportable to IDPH’s Communicable Disease Section. Diseases or conditions repealed and individual cases no longer reportable in I-NEDSS:
column6: - 690.362 Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)
column7: - 690.400 Enterotoxigenic E. coli, Enteropathogenic E. coli and Enteroinvasive E. coli (cases of shiga toxin producing E. coli are still reportable)
column9: - 690.658 Staphylococcus aureus, Methicillin Resistant (MRSA) Infection, Clusters of Two or More Laboratory Confirmed Cases Occurring in Community Settings
column10: - 690.660 Staphylococcus aureus, Methicillin Resistant (MRSA), Any Occurrence in an Infant Less Than 61 Days of Age
column13: Cases of these diseases with an onset in 2018 should still be investigated and reported via I-NEDSS. Any cases reported since 1/1/2019 should be closed as not-a-case. Outbreaks of these diseases or conditions remain reportable through the Outbreak Reporting System (ORS) and should continue to be investigated.
column15:
Please see the attachment for full details.

","Amendments to the IDPH Communicable Disease Code (Rules and Regulations for Communicable Disease Control and Immunizations - 77 Illinois Administrative Code 690) were adopted on Friday,February 8, 2019. The primary change was the repeal of all or part of six diseases or conditions.

column1: Following is a summary of the changes for the diseases reportable to IDPH's Communicable Disease Section.
Following is a summary of the changes for the diseases reportable to IDPH's Communicable Disease Section. Diseases or conditions repealed and individual cases no longer reportable in I-NEDSS:
- 690.362 Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)
- 690.400 Enterotoxigenic E. coli, Enteropathogenic E. coli and Enteroinvasive E. coli (cases of shiga toxin producing E. coli are still reportable)
- 690.480 Leprosy (Hansen's Disease)
- 690.658 Staphylococcus aureus, Methicillin Resistant (MRSA) Infection, Clusters of Two or More Laboratory Confirmed Cases Occurring in Community Settings
- 690.660 Staphylococcus aureus, Methicillin Resistant (MRSA), Any Occurrence in an Infant Less Than 61 Days of Age
- 690.752 Yersiniosis

Cases of these diseases with an onset in 2018 should still be investigated and reported via I-NEDSS. Any cases reported since 1/1/2019 should be closed as not-a-case. Outbreaks of these diseases or conditions remain reportable through the Outbreak Reporting System (ORS) and should continue to be investigated.
Please see the attachment for full details.",True,

column2:
As laboratory testing methods and information technology continue to improve, it is important for the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) to assess the current capacity of laboratories within its jurisdiction to perform and report laboratory results for various reportable conditions. The CDPH Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STD) Program requests that you kindly complete this comprehensive survey of your laboratory’s testing and reporting capabilities for STDs. Your prompt response will be much appreciated.

IDPH Health Advisory: Temporary Visitor Restrictions During Flu Season,2019-01-31T20:29:21.000,46652682,Influenza,,Low,IDPH Health Advisory: Temporary Visitor Restrictions During Flu Season,"<div>
column2: IDPH has issued a Health Advisory regarding temporary visitor restriction policies.
column4: Influenza activity continues to increase in the United States and has reached widespread activity levels in Illinois. Many counties have experienced high levels of influenza-like illness (characterized as fever of 100ºF [37.8ºC] or higher plus cough and/or sore throat), increases in influenza-related ICU admissions, long-term care facility outbreaks, and increases in positive laboratory specimens.
column6: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) recommends that hospitals implement the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC) comprehensive influenza prevention and control recommendations, Prevention Strategies for Seasonal Influenza in Healthcare Settings.
column8: During times of increased incidence of influenza-like illness in the community, IDPH supports implementation of temporary visitor restriction policies in hospitals which may include the following:
column11: Do not allow visitation by persons less than 18 years of age,
column14: Limit the number of visitors to two per patient at any one time,
