","IDPH has issued a Health Advisory regarding temporary visitor restriction policies.

column1: Influenza activity continues to increase in the United States and has reached widespread activity levels in Illinois. Many counties have experienced high levels of influenza-like illness (characterized as fever of 100ºF \[37.8ºC\] or higher plus cough and/or sore throat), increases in influenza-related ICU admissions, long-term care facility outbreaks, and increases in positive laboratory specimens.

The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) recommends that hospitals implement the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) comprehensive influenza prevention and control recommendations, [Prevention Strategies for Seasonal Influenza in Healthcare Settings](https://www.cdc.gov/flu/professionals/infectioncontrol/healthcaresettings.htm).
During times of increased incidence of influenza-like illness in the community, IDPH supports implementation of temporary visitor restriction policies in hospitals which may include the following:
* Do not allow visitation by persons less than 18 years of age,
* Limit the number of visitors to two per patient at any one time,

* Promote compliance with Hand Hygiene and [Respiratory Hygiene/Cough Etiquette](http://IDPH has issued a Health Advisory regarding temporary visitor resrticition policies. Influenza activity continues to increase in the United States and has reached widespread activity levels in Illinois. Many counties have experienced high levels of influenza-like illness (characterized as fever of 100ºF [37.8ºC] or higher plus cough and/or sore throat), increases in influenza-related ICU admissions, long-term care facility outbreaks, and increases in positive laboratory specimens. The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) recommends that hospitals implement the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC) comprehensive influenza prevention and control recommendations, Prevention Strategies for Seasonal Influenza in Healthcare Settings. During times of increased incidence of influenza-like illness in the community, IDPH supports implementation of temporary visitor restriction policies in hospitals which may include the following: Do not allow visitation by persons less than 18 years of age, Limit the number of visitors to two per patient at any one time, Promote compliance with Hand Hygiene and Respiratory Hygiene/Cough Etiquette, Assess visitors for symptoms of acute respiratory illness (fever, cough, sore throat), Request that visitors with acute respiratory illness symptoms not visit, but if they insist, require a mask be worn, and Limit visits to patients in isolation for influenza to persons who are necessary for the patients’ emotional well-being and care. Exemptions to these temporary visitor restrictions are permissible at the discretion of the hospital’s Infection Prevention and Control departments for circumstances including, but not limited to, end-of-life situations. Hospitals should continue to implement these temporary visitor restriction policies until the state influenza activity level falls to “Sporadic” activity level or below. Please read the attached Health Advisory for the entire report. For questions on influenza please contact (312) 746-5911. Information on INfluenza, including Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza.),
* Assess visitors for symptoms of acute respiratory illness (fever, cough, sore throat),
* Request that visitors with acute respiratory illness symptoms not visit, but if they insist, require a mask be worn, and
* Limit visits to patients in isolation for influenza to persons who are necessary for the patients' emotional well-being and care.

Exemptions to these temporary visitor restrictions are permissible at the discretion of the hospital's Infection Prevention and Control departments for circumstances including, but not limited to, end-of-life situations.
Hospitals should continue to implement these temporary visitor restriction policies until the state influenza activity level falls to ""Sporadic"" activity level or below.
Please read the attached Health Advisory for the entire report.
For questions on influenza please contact (312) 746-5911. Information on INfluenza, including Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,

IDPH Memo: Recommendations for the Implementation of Empiric Contact Precautions for Candida Auris,2019-01-29T21:21:04.000,46652681,Infectious Disease,,Low,Recommendations for the Implementation of Empiric Contact Precautions for C.auris and Updated CDC C. auris Disinfection Guidance,"<div>
column2: As noted in the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) Health Alert released in September 2018, health care facilities, especially acute care hospitals, should consider the following for patients with a tracheostomy or on mechanical ventilation admitted from any skilled nursing facility or long-term acute care hospital regardless of known Candida auris (C.auris) infection or colonization.
column4: 1. Place the patient in a private room.
column5: 2. Initiate Standard and Contact Precautions.
column6: 3. Perform daily and terminal cleaning/disinfection of the patient’s room with a sporicidal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) List K agent.
column8: Shared equipment and common treatment areas should also be cleaned and disinfected with an EPA List K agent after patient use and treatment. Per updated CDC guidance, when use of products on List K is not feasible, the following products may be used for surface disinfection:
column10: - Oxivir Tb
column11: - Clorox Healthcare Hydrogen Peroxide Cleaner Disinfectant
column15: The decision to implement these recommendations should be guided by a facility’s likelihood of admitting patients with multidrug-resistant organisms such as C. auris. These recommendations have been made to decrease the transmission within and between health care facilities in cases where an individual’s C. auris infection or colonization status is unknown. If a facility decides to implement these recommendations several considerations should be taken:
column17: 1. It is important for all facilities to distinguish between patients on Contact Precautions due to documented infection or colonization with C. auris based current or past laboratory testing, from patients who are empirically placed on Contact Precautions based on risk factors. For
column18: example, we have advised facilities to consider implementing empiric Contact Precautions for patients with a tracheostomy or on mechanical ventilation admitted from any skilled nursing facility or long-term acute care hospital.
column20: 2. During the process of inter-facility communication (i.e. communication with another facility), staff should only communicate that a patient is infected or colonized with C. auris if there is documented identification of C. auris based on current or past laboratory testing.
column22: 3. As a reminder, facilities should be able to confirm a patient’s past C. auris infection or colonization history by querying the XDRO registry.
column26: Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Shannon Xydis at 312-746-0416 for any additional information.
column29: ","As noted in the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) Health Alert released in September 2018, health care facilities, especially acute care hospitals, should consider the following for patients with a tracheostomy or on mechanical ventilation admitted from any skilled nursing facility or long-term acute care hospital regardless of known Candida auris (C.auris) infection or colonization.

column1: 1. Place the patient in a private room.
2. Initiate Standard and Contact Precautions.
3. Perform daily and terminal cleaning/disinfection of the patient's room with a sporicidal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) List K agent.

Shared equipment and common treatment areas should also be cleaned and disinfected with an EPA List K agent after patient use and treatment. Per updated CDC guidance, when use of products on List K is not feasible, the following products may be used for surface disinfection:
- Oxivir Tb
- Clorox Healthcare Hydrogen Peroxide Cleaner Disinfectant
- Prime Sani-Cloth Wipe
- Super Sani-Cloth Wipe

The decision to implement these recommendations should be guided by a facility's likelihood of admitting patients with multidrug-resistant organisms such as C. auris. These recommendations have been made to decrease the transmission within and between health care facilities in cases where an individual's C. auris infection or colonization status is unknown. If a facility decides to implement these recommendations several considerations should be taken:

1. It is important for all facilities to distinguish between patients on Contact Precautions due to documented infection or colonization with C. auris based current or past laboratory testing, from patients who are empirically placed on Contact Precautions based on risk factors. For

example, we have advised facilities to consider implementing empiric Contact Precautions for patients with a tracheostomy or on mechanical ventilation admitted from any skilled nursing facility or long-term acute care hospital.

2. During the process of inter-facility communication (i.e. communication with another facility), staff should only communicate that a patient is infected or colonized with C. auris if there is documented identification of C. auris based on current or past laboratory testing.
3. As a reminder, facilities should be able to confirm a patient's past C. auris infection or colonization history by querying the XDRO registry.
Please email [CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org](mailto:CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org) or contact Shannon Xydis at 312-746-0416 for any additional information.",True,

","The Chicago Flu Update for Week 03 has been published. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago [Walk-In Immunization Clinics](https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/immunizations_walk-inclinics.html) is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](https://chicagoflushots.org/).

column1: Currently, the risk of influenza infection continues to increase.
For the week of January 13-19, 2019, 13 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, 491 of 12,144 (4.0%) specimens tested for influenza have been positive; 486 typed as influenza A (169 H1N1pdm09, 10 H3N2, and 307 unknown subtype \[subtyping not performed or not all subtypes tested\]) and five typed as influenza B.

ESSENCE is an electronic syndromic surveillance system that utilizes the chief complaints of patients visiting emergency departments to monitor for influenza-like illness. Currently, ESSENCE captures every emergency department visit in the city on a daily basis. For the week of January 13-19, 2019, 750 of the 24,158 (3.1%) total emergency department visits were due to influenza-like illness.
The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",False,

IDPH: Hepatitis A Guidance for Healthcare Workers and Healthcare Facilities,2019-01-24T16:12:00.000,46652577,Vaccine Preventable,,Low,IDPH: Hepatitis A Guidance for Healthcare Workers and Healthcare Facilities,"
column2: Given the continued Hepatitis A outbreak in Illinois, it is increasingly important that Hepatitis A vaccinations are made easily available to high-risk populations such as men who have sex with men (MSM), users of illicit drugs (both IV and non-IV), and/or individuals experiencing homeless/insecure housing.  For those individuals who are unable to afford vaccination, CDPH has partnered with Howard Brown Health Centers to serve as walk-in referral sites for Hepatitis A vaccination.
column4: Reach out to ChicagoVFC@cityofchicago.org if you are an Emergency Department willing to distribute Hep A vaccine or you have questions about how to make Hep A vaccine available to your patients.
column6: Visit www.chicagohan.org/HepA for local updates on Hepatitis A activity and recommendations.
column10: Clinicians and health care facilities in Illinois are critical partners with public health officials in our efforts to prevent a larger statewide outbreak. The Illinois Department of Public Health urges clinicians to take the following important steps to protect high-risk patients and mitigate the spread of illness.
column13: Vaccinate Highest Risk Individuals: Clinicians and facilities are asked to identify and implement strategies to increase hepatitis A vaccination among the following groups:
column14: <li>
column16: a. Persons who use injection and non-injection drugs,
column22: c. Persons who are or have been recently incarcerated,
column25: d. Men who have sex with men, and
column26: <li>
column28: e. Persons with chronic liver disease, including chronic hepatitis B or C.
column29:
Download the attached Health Advisory for additional information.

","Given the continued Hepatitis A outbreak in Illinois, it is increasingly important that Hepatitis A vaccinations are made easily available to high-risk populations such as men who have sex with men (MSM), users of illicit drugs (both IV and non-IV), and/or individuals experiencing homeless/insecure housing. For those individuals who are unable to afford vaccination, CDPH has partnered with [Howard Brown Health Centers](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/240524/CDPHHepADec072018_Final.pdf/2770527e-f1bb-4bd1-8c31-4f38a6a27e03){#LPlnk870193} to serve as walk-in referral sites for Hepatitis A vaccination.

column1: Reach out to **ChicagoVFC@cityofchicago.org** if you are an Emergency Department willing to distribute Hep A vaccine or youhave questions about how to make Hep A vaccine available to your patients.
Visit [www.chicagohan.org/HepA](http://www.chicagohan.org/HepA){#LPlnk337413} for local updates on Hepatitis A activity and recommendations.
++**ACTIONS FOR CLINICIANS AND HEALTHCARE FACILITIES:**++

Clinicians and health care facilities in Illinois are critical partners with public health officials in our efforts to prevent a larger statewide outbreak. The Illinois Department of Public Health urges clinicians to take the following important steps to protect high-risk patients and mitigate the spread of illness.
1. Vaccinate Highest Risk Individuals: Clinicians and facilities are asked to identify and implement strategies to increase hepatitis A vaccination among the following groups:
* a. Persons who use injection and non-injection drugs,
* b. Persons who are homeless,
* c. Persons who are or have been recently incarcerated,
* d. Men who have sex with men, and
* e. Persons with chronic liver disease, including chronic hepatitis B or C.
Download the attached Health Advisory for additional information.",True,
IDPH: Call for Cases: Burkholderia cepacia Infections,2019-01-24T16:09:22.000,46652677,Infectious Disease,,Low,IDPH: Call for Cases: Burkholderia cepacia Infections,"<div>
column2: The Illinois Department of Public Health is investigating five patients with laboratory-diagnosed Burkholderia cepacia infections at a central Illinois hospital. The patients’ underlying conditions were variable, but none had cystic fibrosis.
column4: Clinicians, laboratories, and infection control practitioners: Please notify the Chicago Department of Public Health of any Chicago patients who do NOT have cystic fibrosis and were diagnosed with culture-positive B. cepacia on or after November 1, 2018.
column6: Clinical laboratories: Please hold specimens/isolates positive for B. cepacia from non-cystic fibrosis patients for 30 days in case additional testing is needed.
column8: B. cepacia is a group or “complex” of bacteria most often found in soil and water. People who have weakened immune systems or chronic lung conditions are particularly susceptible to infections. The bacteria are often resistant to common antibiotics. Prior outbreaks of B. cepacia infections have been linked to nasal sprays, liquid stool softeners, and saline flushes. Person-to-person transmission and transmission within healthcare facilities is possible.
column10: Reports may faxed to: 312-746-4683. Reports should include: any positive culture results, specimen source, dates of hospital admission (if applicable), current diagnosis, and underlying conditions.
column12: Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information.","The Illinois Department of Public Health is investigating five patients with laboratory-diagnosed Burkholderia cepacia infections at a central Illinois hospital. The patients' underlying conditions were variable, but none had cystic fibrosis.

column1: Clinicians, laboratories, and infection control practitioners: Please notify the Chicago Department of Public Health of any Chicago patients who do NOT have cystic fibrosis and were diagnosed with culture-positive B. cepacia on or after November 1, 2018.
Clinical laboratories: Please hold specimens/isolates positive for B. cepacia from non-cystic fibrosis patients for 30 days in case additional testing is needed.

B. cepacia is a group or ""complex"" of bacteria most often found in soil and water. People who have weakened immune systems or chronic lung conditions are particularly susceptible to infections. The bacteria are often resistant to common antibiotics. Prior outbreaks of B. cepacia infections have been linked to nasal sprays, liquid stool softeners, and saline flushes. Person-to-person transmission and transmission within healthcare facilities is possible.
Reports may faxed to: 312-746-4683. Reports should include: any positive culture results, specimen source, dates of hospital admission (if applicable), current diagnosis, and underlying conditions.
Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information.",True,

column2:
As laboratory testing methods and information technology continue to improve, it is important for the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) to assess the current capacity of laboratories within its jurisdiction to perform and report laboratory results for various reportable conditions. The CDPH Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STD) Program requests that you kindly complete this comprehensive survey of your laboratory’s testing and reporting capabilities for STDs. Your prompt response will be much appreciated.

column3: Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of City of Chicago Walk-In Immunization Clinics is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to www.chicagoflushots.org.
column5: Currently, the risk of influenza infection continues to increase.
column6: For the week of December 30, 2018-January 5, 2019, nine influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported

column9: For the week of December 30, 2018-January 5, 2019, 92 of the 3,831 (2.4%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is similar to both Illinois (2.9%) and Region 5 (2.6%) but lower than the U.S. (3.5%).

Healthcare facilities can report cases to the Chicago Department of Public Health via the Illinois National Electronic Disease Surveillance System (INEDSS).

","The Chicago Flu Update for Week 01 has been published.

column1: Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of [City of Chicago Walk-In Immunization Clinics](https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/immunizations_walk-inclinics.html) is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](https://chicagoflushots.org/).
Currently, the risk of influenza infection continues to increase.
For the week of December 30, 2018-January 5, 2019, nine influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported

Since September 30, 2018, 32 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; 27 were positive for influenza A (18 H1N1pdm09 and 9 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and five were positive for influenza B

For the week of December 30, 2018-January 5, 2019, with 5 laboratories reporting, 86 of the 1,014 (8.5%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 77 typed as influenza A (29 H1N1pdm09, 3 H3N2, and 45 unknown subtype) and one typed as influenza B.

For the week of December 30, 2018-January 5, 2019, 92 of the 3,831 (2.4%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is similar to both Illinois (2.9%) and Region 5 (2.6%) but lower than the U.S. (3.5%).

The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on[reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/39923/Reporting%20Influenza-Associated%20ICU%20Hospitalizations) stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting. Healthcare facilities can report cases to the Chicago Department of Public Health via the Illinois National Electronic Disease Surveillance System ([INEDSS](https://dph.partner.illinois.gov)).
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.

For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: [https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.](https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza)",True,

VIM-CRPA Infections Among Adult Patients Returning to the United States,2019-01-11T15:57:18.000,46652184,Hospital Notification,,Low,VIM-CRPA Infections Among Adult Patients Returning to the United States,"<div>
column2: Verona Integron-mediated Metallo-β-lactamase-producing carbapenem-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (VIM-CRPA) infections among adult patients returning to the United States after undergoing invasive procedures
column6: Providers caring for patients with a history of recent invasive procedures in Mexico should be aware of the potential for infections caused by resistant pathogens like VIM-CRPA.
column7: Report to the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) any carbapenem-resistant P. aeruginosa surgical site infections in patients following invasive procedures in Mexico.
column8: Patients admitted to healthcare facilities in the U.S. following an overnight stay in a healthcare facility outside the U.S. (within the last 6 months) should undergo rectal screening for carbapenemase-producing organisms.
column10: Mechanism testing for carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) and CRPA is available free of charge via the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network. Please contact CDPH prior to submission to obtain approval and a submission code. Email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225.
column12: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) was notified beginning on September 28, 2018 through the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network (https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/solutions-initiative/ar-lab-network.html) of 10 Verona Integron-mediated Metallo-β-lactamase-producing carbapenem-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (VIM-CRPA) infections among adult patients returning to the United States after undergoing invasive procedures (e.g. endoscopy, surgery) in Mexico. Seven patients reported receiving bariatric surgery in Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico during September 2018 to November, 2018. Out of these seven, six reported undergoing surgery at Grand View Hospital in the city of Tijuana.
column14: Important information for healthcare providers
column16: Providers caring for patients with a history of recent invasive procedures in Mexico should be aware of the potential for infections caused by resistant pathogens like VIM-CRPA. For those with signs of infection, U.S. healthcare providers should obtain cultures, perform antimicrobial susceptibility testing to guide treatment, and have any carbapenem-resistant strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacteriaceae tested for VIM and other plasmid-mediated carbapenemases.
column18: Additionally, please report to the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) any carbapenem-resistant P. aeruginosa surgical site infections in patients following invasive procedures in Mexico.
column20: CDC continues to recommend that patients admitted to healthcare facilities in the U.S. following an overnight stay in a healthcare facility outside the U.S. (within the last 6 months) undergo rectal screening for carbapenemase-producing organisms.
column22: Mechanism testing for carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) and CRPA, and rectal screening for carbapenemases are available free of charge via the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network, (https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/solutions-initiative/ar-lab-network.html), which can be accessed through CDPH-Healthcare Associated Infections Unit. Please contact CDPH prior to submission to obtain approval and a submission code. Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information. Laboratory testing reports may faxed to: 312-746-4683. Reports should include antibiotic susceptibility results, and results for any phenotypic/molecular testing performed.
column24: Important information for patients seeking medical care outside of the U.S.
column26: Medical tourism has been associated with complications, including infections caused by antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria not commonly seen in the U.S. Patients who are considering seeking medical care overseas should be aware of this risk. Information about medical tourism is available at: https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2018/the-pre-travel-consultation/medical-tourism
column28: Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information.
column30:
For more important information for healthcare providers, download the attached Health Alert.

","**Verona Integron-mediated Metallo-β-lactamase-producing carbapenem-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (VIM-CRPA) infections among adult patients returning to the United States after undergoing invasive procedures**

column1: **Summary and Action Items:**
**Providers caring for patients with a history of recent invasive procedures in Mexico should be aware of the potential for infections caused by resistant pathogens like VIM-CRPA.**
**Report to the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) any carbapenem-resistant P. aeruginosa surgical site infections in patients following invasive procedures in Mexico.**

**Patients admitted to healthcare facilities in the U.S. following an overnight stay in a healthcare facility outside the U.S. (within the last 6 months) should undergo rectal screening for carbapenemase-producing organisms.**

Mechanism testing for carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) and CRPA is available free of charge via the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network. Please contact CDPH prior to submission to obtain approval and a submission code. Email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) was notified beginning on September 28, 2018 through the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network (<https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/solutions-initiative/ar-lab-network.html>) of 10 Verona Integron-mediated Metallo-β-lactamase-producing carbapenem-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (VIM-CRPA) infections among adult patients returning to the United States after undergoing invasive procedures (e.g. endoscopy, surgery) in Mexico. Seven patients reported receiving bariatric surgery in Tijuana, Baja California, Mexico during September 2018 to November, 2018. Out of these seven, six reported undergoing surgery at Grand View Hospital in the city of Tijuana.
**Important information for healthcare providers**

Providers caring for patients with a history of recent invasive procedures in Mexico should be aware of the potential for infections caused by resistant pathogens like VIM-CRPA. For those with signs of infection, U.S. healthcare providers should obtain cultures, perform antimicrobial susceptibility testing to guide treatment, and have any carbapenem-resistant strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacteriaceae tested for VIM and other plasmid-mediated carbapenemases.
Additionally, please report to the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) any carbapenem-resistant P. aeruginosa surgical site infections in patients following invasive procedures in Mexico.

CDC continues to recommend that patients admitted to healthcare facilities in the U.S. following an overnight stay in a healthcare facility outside the U.S. (within the last 6 months) undergo rectal screening for carbapenemase-producing organisms.

Mechanism testing for carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) and CRPA, and rectal screening for carbapenemases are available free of charge via the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network, (<https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/solutions-initiative/ar-lab-network.html>), which can be accessed through CDPH-Healthcare Associated Infections Unit. Please contact CDPH prior to submission to obtain approval and a submission code. Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information. Laboratory testing reports may faxed to: 312-746-4683. Reports should include antibiotic susceptibility results, and results for any phenotypic/molecular testing performed.
**Important information for patients seeking medical care outside of the U.S.**

Medical tourism has been associated with complications, including infections caused by antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria not commonly seen in the U.S. Patients who are considering seeking medical care overseas should be aware of this risk. Information about medical tourism is available at: <https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2018/the-pre-travel-consultation/medical-tourism>
Please email CDPHHAIAR@cityofchicago.org or contact Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 for any additional information.
For more important information for healthcare providers, download the attached Health Alert.",True,

column1: VFC News Bulletin -- January 8, 2019
PLEASE READ AND SHARE WITH ALL STAFF IN YOUR OFFICE!

Happy New Year! We are pleased to announce a new look for the Chicago VFC News Bulletin. The news bulletin serves to keep you aware of emerging VFC program, vaccine and vaccine-preventable disease updates.
**In This Issue**
* In-person I-CARE Training Sessions
* Digital Data Logger Trade in Program
* Webinar on Tools Pediatricians Can Use to Advocate for Children and Families who have Immigrated
* New CDC Video: The Journey of your Child's Vaccine",True,

","**Chicago Department of Public Health Emergency Preparedness Program No cost Training in Psychological First Aid: Basic Principles**

column1: If you are a provider and want to learn how to support people experiencing a disaster, Psychological First Aid (PFA) provides you with effective ways to help survivors manage their distress and needs. Psychological First Aid is a nonclinical intervention and formal healthcare training is not required.
Participants will learn to:
* provide survivors with early psychosocial support during a disaster.
* use PFA intervention strategies to prevent further harm and help survivors cope.
* support provider care before, during, and after disaster care.
Choose either training session, **February 11th** or **March 14^th^**, 2019. Each session meets from 9:00 am to 3:00 pm. Lunch is on your own, noon to 1 pm.
CDPH Training Center 1642 N. Besly Court, Chicago. Free off street parking.
**To register, choose a session and send to** [**nikoleta.boukydis@cityofchicago.org**](mailto:nikoleta.boukydis@cityofchicago.org).",False,

CCN: Weathering the Winter: Keep Warm and Safe This Winter Season-Correction issued with attachments,2019-01-07T22:23:51.000,46652179,CCN Announcement,,Low,CCN: Weathering the Winter: Keep Warm and Safe This Winter Season,"
column2: Bitter cold temperatures are more than an inconvenience; they pose a serious threat to health and safety. The City of Chicago has many services available to help residents weather the winter months. Anyone seeking access to warming centers and/or experiencing insufficient heat are being encouraged to contact 3-1-1 for immediate assistance. Download the included attachement for information on Warming Centers in Chicago. You'll find the information in English, Spanish, and Polish.
column3:
This is a message for the Community Communication Network (CCN). The CCN is an collaboration between CDPH and CCDPH. For general information on the HAN, contact the Help Desk at 312-747-8789 or hanhelpdesk@cityofchicago.org.  For health information regarding suburban Cook County, contact Porsha Robinsonat probinson@cookcountyhhs.org. For health information regarding Chicago, contact Darnell Thomas at darnell.thomas@cityofchicago.org.

column1: Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a list of [City of Chicago Walk-In Immunization Clinics](https://www.chicago.gov/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/immunizations_walk-inclinics.html) is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](https://chicagoflushots.org/).
Currently, the risk of influenza infection continues to increase.
For the week of December 23-29, 2018, seven influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, 23 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; 19 were positive for influenza A (11 H1N1pdm09 and 8 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and four were positive for influenza B.

For the week of December 23-29, 2018, with 6 laboratories reporting, 78 of the 922 (8.5%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 77 typed as influenza A (29 H1N1pdm09, 3 H3N2 and 45 unknown subtype) and one typed as influenza B.

For the week of December 23-29, 2018, 113 of the 3,496 (3.2%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is similar to both Illinois (3.3%) and Region 5 (3.7%) but slightly lower than the U.S. (4.1%).

The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on[reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/39923/Reporting%20Influenza-Associated%20ICU%20Hospitalizations) stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting. Healthcare facilities can report cases to the Chicago Department of Public Health via the Illinois National Electronic Disease Surveillance System ([INEDSS](https://dph.partner.illinois.gov)).
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.

For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: [https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.](https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza)",True,

For the week of December 9-15, 2018, four influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, 11 influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; seven were positive for influenza A (4 H1N1pdm09 and 3 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and four were positive for influenza B.

For the week of December 9-15, 2018, with 6 laboratories reporting, 19 of the 762 (2.5%) specimens tested for influenza were positive; 18 typed as influenza A (8 H1N1pdm09 and 10 unknown subtype) and 1 typed as influenza B.

The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on[reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/39923/Reporting%20Influenza-Associated%20ICU%20Hospitalizations) stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting. Healthcare facilities can report cases to the Chicago Department of Public Health via the Illinois National Electronic Disease Surveillance System ([INEDSS](https://dph.partner.illinois.gov)).
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.

For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: [https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.](https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza)",True,

","**Key Messages**

column1: * In the past 24 hours, two hospitals in southern suburban Cook County have reported 8 patients with symptoms ranging from confusion to cardiorespiratory arrest and death after reportedly using crack cocaine.

* The presenting symptoms are more consistent with an opioid overdose and the symptomatic surviving patients responded to naloxone. The individuals needed 6 to 10 mg of naloxone to obtain an adequate response.

* First responders, substance use treatment providers, and hospitals may see an influx of patients with a history of crack cocaine use presenting with symptoms consistent with an opioid overdose over the next few days.
**Action Steps**
* Consider use of naloxone to treat patients with unusual symptoms after using crack cocaine.
* EMS systems and hospitals may need to stock additional naloxone for treatment of affected patients.
* **Report potential cases** of contaminated crack cocaine to the **Illinois Poison Center at 1-800-222-1222** for tracking purposes and treatment recommendations as needed.
Please see the attached HAN for more information.",True,

","**Summary and Action Items**

column1: 1. To provide information and resources regarding identification and management of mumps, especially in college students returning home for break.
2. To remind providers and local health departments to remain vigilant in identifying cases.
**Background**

Mumps is a viral illness that classically leads to parotid salivary gland swelling. Since the pre-vaccine era, there has been a more than 99% decrease in mumps cases in the United State. In recent years, however, there has been an increase in cases, mainly due to mumps outbreaks in settings where people often have close contact with one another, like college campuses. This is despite high vaccination coverage rates.

There has been a recent outbreak of mumps at Lewis University in Romeoville, Illinois, as well as numerous other mumps outbreaks nationwide. Since many colleges and universities nationwide will be dismissing for break, this statewide notification is being sent to remind health care providers and local health departments to be vigilant in looking for signs and symptoms of mumps, especially in those attending college.
**Contact**

Clinicians should contact their [local health department](http://www.idph.state.il.us/LHDMap/HealthRegions.aspx) with additional questions and to report suspect or confirmed cases of mumps. LHD may contact the Vaccine Preventable Disease staff at 217-782-2016.
Download attachment for full details.
For information regarding mumps reporting to CDPH, visit: [www.chicagohan.org/mumps](http://www.chicagohan.org/mumps).",True,

column3: PROVIDERS:
column4: ·        Have a low threshold to report clinical suspicion for hepatitis A in high risk individuals to Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH). High risk individuals include those who are homeless or living in transient housing, men who have sex with men, users of injection and non-injection drugs, and/or individuals with a history of incarceration.
column5: ·        Use this Hepatitis A ER reporting form if you are in the ER and have clinical suspicion for hepatitis A in a high risk individual.

","As described in the attached SIREN alert, Hepatitis A activity continues to increase in Illinois. Though currently there are no outbreak associated cases in Chicago, we continue to recommend the following, as posted on [www.chicagohan.org/HepatitisA](http://www.chicagohan.org/HepatitisA) :

column1: **PROVIDERS:**

· Have a low threshold to report clinical suspicion for hepatitis A in high risk individuals to Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH). Call the provider reporting hotline: **312-743-9000** or **311** on evenings or weekends to report. High risk individuals include those who are homeless or living in transient housing, men who have sex with men, users of injection and non-injection drugs, and/or individuals with a history of incarceration.

· Use this [Hepatitis A ER reporting form](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/93622/HepAERreportingform_12151017/5ac6b44e-9bcd-49a0-a21e-2c695d40ab25) if you are in the ER and have clinical suspicion for hepatitis A in a high risk individual.

· Vaccinate high risk patients for hepatitis A now. If you do not stock hepatitis A vaccine, considering purchasing or email[vaccine@cityofchicago.org](mailto:vaccine@cityofchicago.org) to discuss further. See [December 7, 2018 HAN alert](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/240524/CDPHHepADec072018_Final.pdf/2770527e-f1bb-4bd1-8c31-4f38a6a27e03) for more details on vaccination referral locations.
· Consider repeating non-reactive (NR) hepatitis A IgM results in one week for clinically consistent cases.
**LABORATORIES:**
· Save all reactive hepatitis A IgM specimens for 30 days.",True,

Laboratory investigation confirmed brodifacoum exposure in at least 150 patients. There have been at least eight (8) fatalities. Vitamin K1 continues to be the recommended therapy. column89: 1.     CDC recommends that people do not use synthetic cannabinoid products. column125: Please see attachment for further details.","**Summary**

column1: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is providing information on: 1) the current status of a multistate outbreak of coagulopathy from exposure to synthetic cannabinoid products containing a vitamin K-epoxide cycle antagonist, brodifacoum; 2) the emergence of 2 new clinical scenarios; and 3) recommendations to help clinicians make decisions related to these 2 new clinical scenarios.

This is an update to the Health Alert Network (HAN) advisory released on May 25, 2018 titled *Outbreak of* *Life-threatening Coagulopathy Associated with Synthetic Cannabinoids Use*(<https://emergency.cdc.gov/han/han00410.asp>).
**Outbreak Update**

Since the index patient with hypocoagulopathy associated with synthetic cannabinoids use was identified on March 8, 2018 in Illinois, at least 324 people have presented to healthcare facilities with serious bleeding from possible exposure. The largest number of patients were in Illinois (164), followed by Wisconsin (86), Maryland (44), Florida (6), Pennsylvania (6), Missouri (5), North Carolina (5), Indiana (5), Kentucky (1), Virginia (1), and West Virginia (1). Laboratory investigation confirmed brodifacoum exposure in at least 150 patients. There have been at least eight (8) fatalities. Vitamin K1 continues to be the recommended therapy. Since the original HAN advisory on May 25, 2018, two (2) new clinical scenarios have emerged:
1. Several patients have outpatient follow-up blood brodifacoum concentrations that are higher than their initial blood brodifacoum concentrations.
2. At least one patient has become pregnant since starting outpatient oral Vitamin K1 treatment.

When patients are found to have outpatient follow-up blood brodifacoum concentrations higher than their initial blood brodifacoum concentrations, it strongly suggests that they have continued or resumed using synthetic cannabinoid products containing brodifacoum while on oral vitamin K1 therapy. The consequences of re-exposure to brodifacoum include:
1. Risk of life-threatening hemorrhage,
2. Oral vitamin K1 dosing may need to be increased, and
3. Oral vitamin K1 treatment duration may need to be extended.

Pregnancies in patients who are on oral vitamin K1 treatment for brodifacoum toxicity are high-risk pregnancies. Brodifacoum crosses the placenta. Both mother and fetus are at risk for serious bleeding. Brodifacoum may also be a teratogen because its chemical structure is similar to warfarin, a known teratogen.
**Recommendations for Clinicians**

1. Maintain a high index of suspicion for continued or resumed use of synthetic cannabinoid products containing brodifacoum in patients who are on oral vitamin K1 therapy. Ask these patients about continued or resumed use of synthetic cannabinoid products.

2. Counsel against resuming or continuing use of synthetic cannabinoid products. Refer patients to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) national helpline, 1-800-662-HELP(4357), a free, confidential, 24/7, 365-day-a-year treatment referral and information service in English and Spanish for individuals and families facing mental and/or substance use disorders; substance abuse counseling is also available.

3. Advise patients that their current oral vitamin K1 dosing may not prevent recurrent coagulopathy from re-exposure to brodifacoum in synthetic cannabinoid products and the duration of oral vitamin K1 treatment may need to be extended.

4. Consider periodic quantitative testing of patients' blood for brodifacoum during outpatient follow-up visits to inform if patients continued or resumed use of synthetic cannabinoid products containing brodifacoum. In addition, serial blood brodifacoum concentrations allow for calculation of blood brodifacoum half-life and assist in determining duration of oral vitamin K1 therapy.

5. Ask all women of childbearing age who are on oral vitamin K1 therapy about the possibility of being pregnant and counsel them about reliable contraceptive techniques. A periodic pregnancy test should be performed on all women of childbearing age who are on oral vitamin K1 therapy. Pregnant patients on oral vitamin K1 should be referred for high-risk pregnancy management and follow-up.
6. Contact your local poison control center (1-800-222-1222) for questions on diagnostic testing and management of these patients.
7. Promptly report possible cases to your local or state health department.
**Recommendations for the Public**

1. CDC recommends that people do not use synthetic cannabinoid products. Synthetic cannabinoid products are always dangerous because it is impossible for people to know what chemicals are in the product, how much they are being exposed to, and how their body will react to the chemicals. The synthetic cannabinoid products associated with this outbreak are especially dangerous because they contain brodifacoum, a chemical used as rat poison that can cause uncontrolled bleeding.

2. People who have used synthetic cannabinoid products in the past three months and are concerned about their health should contact their healthcare provider. Synthetic cannabinoid products users who develop any unusual bruising or bleeding should immediately seek medical attention.

3. People who are currently on oral vitamin K1 treatment for brodifacoum poisoning should not use synthetic cannabinoid products, as this can cause new or worsening bleeding and may prolong the course of vitamin K1 treatment. Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) national helpline, 1-800-662-HELP(4357), is a free, confidential, 24/7, 365-day-a-year treatment referral and information service in English and Spanish for individuals and families facing mental and/or substance use disorders.
4. Women who are currently on oral vitamin K1 treatment for brodifacoum poisoning should use an effective contraceptive method to prevent pregnancy while being treated.
**For More Information**
1. CDC Clinician Outreach and Communication Activity: Outbreak Alert Update: Potential Life-Threatening Vitamin K-Dependent Antagonist Coagulopathy Associated With Synthetic Cannabinoids Use.
++<https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/USCDC/bulletins/21e1a0f>++
2. Synthetic cannabinoids: What are they? What are their effects?++<https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/hsb/chemicals/sc/default.html>++
3. Synthetic cannabinoids: An Overview for Healthcare Providers.++<https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/hsb/chemicals/sc/healthcare.html>++
**Please contact the Illinois Poison Center at 1-800-222-1222 for questions regarding diagnostic testing and treatment regimens for these patients.**
Please see attachment for further details.",True,
Increase in Hepatitis A Activity in East-Central Illinois,2018-12-07T20:33:30.000,46651884,Vaccine Preventable,,Low,Increase in Hepatitis A Activity in East-Central Illinois,"
column2: SUMMARY AND ACTION ITEMS
column5: Amid surrounding ongoing Hepatitis A (HAV) outbreaks in multiple states, Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has started to receive reports of increased activity in East-Central Illinois; the likelihood of travel to Chicago is high, which may lead to subsequent transmission within Chicago.
column6: <li>
column8: Healthcare providers should ensure adequate supply of hepatitis A vaccine and establish systems to vaccinate all adults at high risk of HAV infection, especially persons experiencing homelessness, men who have sex with men (MSM) and/or persons who use injection and non-injection drugs.
column9: Background:Hepatitis A (HAV) outbreaks among persons reporting drug use or homelessness continue in Kentucky, West Virginia, Indiana, Missouri, Ohio, Tennessee and Arkansas and, as of November 3, 2018, over 8,500 outbreak associated cases have been reported from 12 states.  Statewide, Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has not identified an overall increase in the number of acute HAV cases in 2018 compared to 2017. However, most recently, IDPH has identified an increase of cases among men who have sex with men (MSM) in East-Central Illinois. Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) has confirmed 58 HAV cases from January 2017 to present.  Only 2 of the 24 cases reported in 2018 were MSM, though unrelated to the current cluster in East-Central Illinois.
column10: Recently, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) voted unanimously to add “homelessness” as a routine indication for HAV vaccination. We recommend all providers screen their patients and provide HAV vaccine when indicated. While two doses are recommended to complete the series, even one dose provides nearly 95% immunity.  This recommendation adds to the existing routine vaccination guidance for drug use and MSM.
column11: Vaccine availability:CDPH continues to partner with Howard Brown Health Center to make hepatitis A vaccine available to high-risk individuals who are uninsured or unable to pay.  If you cannot provide hepatitis A vaccine or do not currently have stock of hepatitis A vaccine, please refer individuals to any of the following Howard Brown locations. Patients can call to make an appointment at a specific location or present during hours of operation without an appointment and request vaccination.
column12: Please see the attached documents for more information.  Additionally, please go to www.chicagohan.org/HepA for more information.
column13: Report all cases of hepatitis A to the Chicago Department of Public Health
column14:
Contact Communicable Disease Hepatitis Surveillance at (phone) 312-743-9000, (fax) 312-746-6388.

","**SUMMARY AND ACTION ITEMS**

column1: * Amid surrounding ongoing Hepatitis A (HAV) outbreaks in multiple states, Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has started to receive reports of increased activity in East-Central Illinois; the likelihood of travel to Chicago is high, which may lead to subsequent transmission within Chicago.

* Healthcare providers should ensure adequate supply of hepatitis A vaccine and establish systems to vaccinate all adults at high risk of HAV infection, especially persons experiencing homelessness, men who have sex with men (MSM) and/or persons who use injection and non-injection drugs.

**Background:**Hepatitis A (HAV) outbreaks among persons reporting drug use or homelessness continue in Kentucky, West Virginia, Indiana, Missouri, Ohio, Tennessee and Arkansas and, as of November 3, 2018, over 8,500 outbreak associated cases have been reported from 12 states. Statewide, Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has not identified an overall increase in the number of acute HAV cases in 2018 compared to 2017. However, most recently, IDPH has identified an increase of cases among men who have sex with men (MSM) in East-Central Illinois. Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) has confirmed 58 HAV cases from January 2017 to present. Only 2 of the 24 cases reported in 2018 were MSM, though unrelated to the current cluster in East-Central Illinois.

Recently, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) voted unanimously to [add ""homelessness"" as a routine indication for HAV vaccination](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/67/wr/mm6743a3.htm?s_cid=mm6743a3_e). We recommend all providers screen their patients and provide HAV vaccine when indicated. While two doses are recommended to complete the series, even one dose provides nearly 95% immunity. This recommendation adds to the existing [routine vaccination guidance for drug use and MSM](https://www.cdc.gov/hepatitis/outbreaks/InterimOutbreakGuidance-HAV-VaccineAdmin.htm).

**Vaccine availability:** CDPH continues to partner with Howard Brown Health Center to make hepatitis A vaccine available to high-risk individuals who are uninsured or unable to pay. If you cannot provide hepatitis A vaccine or do not currently have stock of hepatitis A vaccine, please refer individuals to any of the following [Howard Brown locations](https://howardbrown.org/health-centers/). Patients can call to make an appointment at a specific location or present during hours of operation without an appointment and request vaccination.
Please see the attached documents for more information. Additionally, please go to [www.chicagohan.org/HepA](https://www.chicagohan.org/HepA) for more information.
**Report all cases of hepatitis A to the Chicago Department of Public Health**{#yui_patched_v3_11_0_1_1544214117868_1189}
Contact Communicable Disease Hepatitis Surveillance at (phone) 312-743-9000, (fax) 312-746-6388.",True,

Call to Report Local Suspect Measles Cases and Assess for Travel to NY/NJ,2018-12-07T19:54:34.000,46651883,Infectious Disease,,Low,Call to Report Local Suspect Measles Cases and Assess for Travel to NY/NJ,"
column2: Summary and Action Items:
column5: Providers should have a high index of suspicion to test for measles in clinically compatible individuals from the Orthodox Jewish community and in persons returning from travel to Israel or affected NY and NJ neighborhoods.
column6: <li>
column8: Providers should contact Chicago Department of Public Health immediately with any suspect measles cases in a clinically compatible case at high risk of exposure to measles.
column11: Report suspect measles casesto the provider reporting hotline 312-743-9000Monday-Friday during working hours. After hours, weekends, and holidays, call 311 and ask for the communicable disease physician on call.
column12: Background: Ongoing measles outbreaks are occurring in the Orthodox Jewish communities in Brooklyn, Rockland County and Orange County New York, and in Ocean County, New Jersey.
column13: Symptoms and Transmission:Measles is a highly communicable viral disease. If measles is suspected, patients should be masked and put in airborne isolation immediately. Incubation period is about 10 days (range 7-21 days) from exposure to onset of fever, and usually 14 days until rash appears. Period of communicability is 4 days before rash appearance until 4 days after rash appearance. Patients typically present with a prodrome: fever plus conjunctivitis, coryza, cough and rarely, Koplik spots (small white spots on an erythematous base on buccal mucosa). A characteristic red blotchy rash appears on day 3-7 of symptoms; it begins on the face, then becomes generalized, and lasts 4-7 days. Leukopenia is common. The disease is more severe in infants and complications include pneumonia, bacterial superinfection, and encephalitis.
column14: Testing: Collect specimens as soon as possible after rash onset. Throat swabs are preferred. Nasal swabs or washes are acceptable but not preferred.If you suspect measles enough to test, call CDPH immediately for consultation, authorization and coordination of diagnostic testing which includes measles IgM antibody testing and the measles RNA real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) at the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) laboratory in Chicago.
column15: Prevention:Routine childhood immunization (e.g. MMR) at age 12-15 months induces immunity in 93% of recipients; the second routine dose at 4-6 years increases immunity levels to 97%.
column16: <li>
column18: CDPH is endorsing a permissive recommendation for expanded MMR vaccination in families with frequent, prolonged, or upcoming travel to locations with ongoing measles outbreaks (as described above).  Remember that it takes 2 weeks for immunity to develop. If given, the dose would not count toward a routine 2-dose schedule. The child would need to be revaccinated at 12-15 months of age and again at 4-6 years of age for a total of 3 doses.
column20:
Visit www.chicagohan.org/measlesfor additional instructions and resources.

","**++Summary and Action Items:++**

column1: * Providers should have a high index of suspicion to test for measles in clinically compatible individuals from the Orthodox Jewish community and in persons returning from travel to Israel or affected NY and NJ neighborhoods.
* Providers should contact Chicago Department of Public Health immediately with any suspect measles cases in a clinically compatible case at high risk of exposure to measles.

* **Report suspect measles casesto the provider reporting hotline 312-743-9000**Monday-Friday during working hours. After hours, weekends, and holidays, call 311 and ask for the communicable disease physician on call.
**Background:**Ongoing measles outbreaks are occurring in the Orthodox Jewish communities in Brooklyn, Rockland County and Orange County New York, and in Ocean County, New Jersey.

**Sy** **mptoms and Transmission:**Measles is a highly communicable viral disease. If measles is suspected, patients should be masked and put in airborne isolation immediately. Incubation period is about 10 days (range 7-21 days) from exposure to onset of fever, and usually 14 days until rash appears. Period of communicability is 4 days before rash appearance until 4 days after rash appearance. Patients typically present with a prodrome: fever plus conjunctivitis, coryza, cough and rarely, Koplik spots (small white spots on an erythematous base on buccal mucosa). A characteristic red blotchy rash appears on day 3-7 of symptoms; it begins on the face, then becomes generalized, and lasts 4-7 days. Leukopenia is common. The disease is more severe in infants and complications include pneumonia, bacterial superinfection, and encephalitis.

**Testing:** Collect specimens as soon as possible after rash onset. Throat swabs are preferred. Nasal swabs or washes are acceptable but not preferred.If you suspect measles enough to test, call CDPH immediately for consultation, [authorization and coordination of diagnostic testing](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/107461/Measles_Isolation_Testing_Reccomendations.pdf/6c5e4a93-f9d1-4420-938c-0d636664de21) which includes measles IgM antibody testing and the measles RNA real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) at the Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) laboratory in Chicago.
**Prevention:**Routine childhood immunization (e.g. MMR) at age 12-15 months induces immunity in 93% of recipients; the second routine dose at 4-6 years increases immunity levels to 97%.

* **CDPH is endorsing a permissive recommendation for expanded MMR vaccination in families with frequent, prolonged, or upcoming travel to locations with ongoing measles outbreaks**(as described above). Remember that it takes 2 weeks for immunity to develop. If given, the dose would not count toward a routine 2-dose schedule. The child would need to be revaccinated at 12-15 months of age and again at 4-6 years of age for a total of 3 doses.
**Visit** [**www.chicagohan.org/measles**](http://www.chicagohan.org/measles)**for additional instructions and resources.**",True,

column2: The Chicago Flu Update for Week 47 has been published.
column3: Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a schedule of City of Chicago influenza vaccination clinics is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to www.chicagoflushots.org.
column4: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is low.
column5: For the week of November 18-24, 2018, no influenza associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.
column6: Since September 30, 2018, six influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; five were positive for influenza A (2 H1N1pdm09 and 3 unknown subtype [subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested]) and one was positive for influenza B.
column7: For the week of November 18-24, 2018, 92 of the 4,066 (2.3%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is similar to Illinois (1.6%), to the U.S. (2.3%) and to Region 5 (1.5%).  For the week of November 18-24, 2018, 476 of the 21,964 (2.2%) total emergency department visits were due to influenza-like illness
column8: The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting. Healthcare facilities can report cases to the Chicago Department of Public Health via the Illinois National Electronic Disease Surveillance System (INEDSS).
column9: Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.

","The Chicago Flu Update for Week 47 has been published.

column1: Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a schedule of [City of Chicago influenza vaccination clinics](https://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/cdph/supp_info/health-protection/2018-influenza-walk-in-clinic-schedule.html) is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](https://chicagoflushots.org/).
Currently, the risk of influenza infection is low.
For the week of November 18-24, 2018, no influenza associated ICU hospitalizations were reported.

Since September 30, 2018, six influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations have been reported; five were positive for influenza A (2 H1N1pdm09 and 3 unknown subtype \[subtyping not attempted or not all subtypes tested\]) and one was positive for influenza B.

For the week of November 18-24, 2018, 92 of the 4,066 (2.3%) reported outpatient clinic visits were due to influenza-like illness, which is similar to Illinois (1.6%), to the U.S. (2.3%) and to Region 5 (1.5%). For the week of November 18-24, 2018, 476 of the 21,964 (2.2%) total emergency department visits were due to influenza-like illness

The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on [reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/39923/Reporting%20Influenza-Associated%20ICU%20Hospitalizations) stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting. Healthcare facilities can report cases to the Chicago Department of Public Health via the Illinois National Electronic Disease Surveillance System ([INEDSS](https://dph.partner.illinois.gov)).
Please read the attached Flu Update for the entire report.

For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: [https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.](https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza)",True,

IDPH Health Advisory: Vibrio CIDT,2018-11-28T22:28:53.000,46651877,Infectious Disease,,Low,IDPH Health Advisory: Vibrio CIDT,"<div>
column2: Summary and Action Items
column4: 1. To inform providers and laboratories of the concern for false positives with the use of culture-independent diagnostic tests (CIDTs) in detection of Vibrio infections.
column6: 2. To remind providers and laboratories to forward specimens positive for Vibrio by CIDT to the IDPH Laboratory for confirmatory testing.
column8: 3. To remind local health departments (LHDs) of appropriate trace back actions for persons with confirmed Vibrio infections and consumption of shellfish.
column10: Vibriosis and cholera are gastrointestinal illnesses caused by Vibrio bacteria. Cholera is caused by toxigenic Vibrio cholerae O1 and O139 strains and is associated with drinking contaminated water. Vibriosis is caused by non-cholerae Vibrio strains, which can naturally be found in coastal waters. Vibriosis is often associated with the consumption of raw or undercooked shellfish (e.g. oysters, mussels, clams and scallops), especially oysters. Skin infections may also occur if a wound is exposed to seawater inhabited by Vibrio. In recent years, the use of CIDTs at hospital laboratories for diagnosing Vibrio infections has increased due to faster turnaround times for results and their ability to test for multiple pathogens.
column14: LHDs will continue to investigate both probable and confirmed cases through case interviews to identify potential Vibrio exposures, particularly consumption of raw shellfish. If a specimen is culture-confirmed, LHDs will do a trace back on any raw shellfish consumed by the patient. The LHD will obtain a copy of the tags, invoices, inspection reports and any other investigative information on the shellfish at the facility (e.g. restaurant or grocery store). If a confirmed case reports consuming shellfish in another state, IDPH will follow-up with the respective state. All documents should be sent to April Caulk, IDPH FDD at dph.food@illinois.gov or faxed to 217-782-0943 for submission to the FDA. Trace backs only need to be completed for confirmed cases or when requested by the Department. IDPH will also continue to review surveillance data to better understand the rise in cases, and the impact of CIDT results on case classifications. Contact Please contact your local health department with any questions about Vibrio infections or the IDPH Communicable Disease Section at 217-782-2016. If you have questions regarding specimen shipping please contact the IDPH Division of Laboratories at 217-782-6562.
column16: Download attached Health Advisory for additional information.
column18: To report a case of vibriosis in a Chicago resident or for questions on vibriosis reporting requirements please contact the CDPH Communicable Disease Program at 312-746-5377 or 312-746-5925.","++Summary and Action Items++

column1: 1. To inform providers and laboratories of the concern for false positives with the use of culture-independent diagnostic tests (CIDTs) in detection of Vibrio infections.
2. To remind providers and laboratories to forward specimens positive for Vibrio by CIDT to the IDPH Laboratory for confirmatory testing.
3. To remind local health departments (LHDs) of appropriate trace back actions for persons with confirmed Vibrio infections and consumption of shellfish.

Vibriosis and cholera are gastrointestinal illnesses caused by Vibrio bacteria. Cholera is caused by toxigenic Vibrio cholerae O1 and O139 strains and is associated with drinking contaminated water. Vibriosis is caused by non-cholerae Vibrio strains, which can naturally be found in coastal waters. Vibriosis is often associated with the consumption of raw or undercooked shellfish (e.g. oysters, mussels, clams and scallops), especially oysters. Skin infections may also occur if a wound is exposed to seawater inhabited by Vibrio. In recent years, the use of CIDTs at hospital laboratories for diagnosing Vibrio infections has increased due to faster turnaround times for results and their ability to test for multiple pathogens.
++Public Health Response++

LHDs will continue to investigate both probable and confirmed cases through case interviews to identify potential Vibrio exposures, particularly consumption of raw shellfish. If a specimen is culture-confirmed, LHDs will do a trace back on any raw shellfish consumed by the patient. The LHD will obtain a copy of the tags, invoices, inspection reports and any other investigative information on the shellfish at the facility (e.g. restaurant or grocery store). If a confirmed case reports consuming shellfish in another state, IDPH will follow-up with the respective state. All documents should be sent to April Caulk, IDPH FDD at [dph.food@illinois.gov](mailto:dph.food@illinois.gov)[](mailto:dph.food@illinois.gov )or faxed to 217-782-0943 for submission to the FDA. Trace backs only need to be completed for confirmed cases or when requested by the Department. IDPH will also continue to review surveillance data to better understand the rise in cases, and the impact of CIDT results on case classifications. Contact Please contact your local health department with any questions about Vibrio infections or the IDPH Communicable Disease Section at 217-782-2016. If you have questions regarding specimen shipping please contact the IDPH Division of Laboratories at 217-782-6562.
Download attached Health Advisory for additional information.

**To report a case of vibriosis in a Chicago resident or for questions on vibriosis reporting requirements please contact the CDPH Communicable Disease Program at 312-746-5377 or 312-746-5925.**",True,

column2: Important Note: You are receiving this notice because your name was included on a list of active pharmaceutical license applicants (as of August 2018). If you ARE NOT continuing your City of Chicago license, you will be removed from the audit process once you alert us to the error (via pharmareplicense@cityofchicago.org).
column4: Dear Licensed Pharmaceutical Representative:
column6: The Chicago Department of Public Health, Pharmaceutical Representative Education Team will start its annual Continuing Education audit to determine compliance with continuing education (CE) requirements per the City of Chicago Ordinance #4–6-310. Using a random selection process, individual pharmaceutical representatives will be identified for inclusion in the audit.
column8: If selected, representatives will receive a separate AUDIT notice via the contact information provided in the license application. The AUDIT selection notice will provide instructions to verify the completion of the 5.0 CE hours prior to renewing a Pharmaceutical License (for a subsequent term). Selected representatives must return all required documents by December 31, 2018.
column10: Please note:   This is a group notice. If you are selected for an audit, you will receive individual correspondence via email. Any questions or concerns may be directed to pharmareplicense@cityofchicago.org.
column13: Thank you.

column16:
Chicago Department of Public Health

column1: Dear Licensed Pharmaceutical Representative:

The Chicago Department of Public Health, Pharmaceutical Representative Education Team will start its annual Continuing Education audit to determine compliance with continuing education (CE) requirements per the City of Chicago Ordinance #4--6-310. Using a random selection process, individual pharmaceutical representatives will be identified for inclusion in the audit.

**If selected** , representatives will receive a **separate** AUDIT notice via the contact information provided in the license application. The AUDIT selection notice will provide instructions to verify the completion of the 5.0 CE hours prior to renewing a Pharmaceutical License (for a subsequent term). Selected representatives must return all required documents by December 31, 2018.

**Please note:** This is a group notice. If you are selected for an audit, you will receive individual correspondence via email. Any questions or concerns may be directed to [pharmareplicense@cityofchicago.org](mailto:pharmareplicense@cityofchicago.org).
Thank you.
**Pharmaceutical Representative Education Team**
Chicago Department of Public Health",False,

","**SUMMARY AND ACTION ITEMS**

column1: * Healthcare providers may see an increase in the number of patients seeking evaluation, testing, prophylaxis or treatment for pertussis due to an ongoing outbreak at a Chicago area childcare center.

* Providers should ask for recent exposure in patients presenting with cough for over 14 days or who report exposure to pertussis. Pertussis vaccination history should not alter plans to test or prophylaxis.
**Background:**

Chicago Department of Public Health has identified a pertussis outbreak at The Gardner School (2850 N Lincoln Ave). Six children 1-3 years of age have been diagnosed to date and approximately 100 individuals have been exposed over the past 2-3 weeks. Staff and parents of exposed children have been instructed to seek medical evaluation to receive either prophylaxis (if asymptomatic) or testing with treatment/prophylaxis (if symptomatic). Patients should be instructed to return to the childcare facility only when treatment is completed or prophylaxis has been initiated. Persons with pertussis are infectious from the beginning of the catarrhal stage (runny nose, sneezing, low-grade fever) through the third week after the onset of paroxysms (multiple, rapid coughs) or until 5 days after the start of effective antimicrobial treatment.
**Recommendations:**

**Suggested** Azithromycin dosing for prophylaxis or treatment: 0-5 months old \[10 mg/kg/day as a single dose for 5 days\]; 6 months and older \[10 mg/kg as a single dose on day 1 (max dose: 500mg), then 5 mg/kg/day (max dose: 250mg) as a single dose on days 2 through 5\]; Adolescents and adults \[500 mg as a single dose on day 1, then 250 mg as a single dose on days 2 through 5\]. For alternative therapies see [Clinical Guidelines for Testing and Treatment of Persons with Pertussis](https://www.chicagohan.org/documents/14171/49101/HealthUpdate_Pertussis_Testing_Treatment_08012012.pdf/c9872fed-b230-4311-914f-e9b2fa4c5aa4).
**For Exposed Patients without Symptoms** : Prescribe antibiotic prophylaxis. See above.
**For Exposed Patients with Symptoms:**
For patients coughing \<21 days:
1. Collect nasopharyngeal swabs or aspirate for pertussis PCR testing.
2. Do not delay treatment with appropriate antibiotics while waiting for laboratory results if there is no alternative diagnosis.

3. Provide documentation that verifies that the individuals are able to return to the daycare (this includes individuals for whom pertussis has been ruled out, children who have completed treatment or begun prophylaxis) and report any pertussis diagnoses to CDPH by calling 312-743-9000 or follow the instructions on [www.chicagohan.org/pertussis](https://www.chicagohan.org/pertussis).

4. Strongly consider antibiotic prophylaxis for all household members if a pregnant woman, an infant less than 12 months old, or anyone with a weakened immune system lives in the household or if the family has regular contact with any known pertussis cases.
**For patients coughing ≥21 days:**
1. Laboratory testing for pertussis is not necessary. CDC does not recommend laboratory testing after 3 weeks of cough since PCR and culture are only sensitive during the first 2 to 3 weeks of cough.
2. For most patients, antibiotic treatment is not required after 21 days of cough, with the exception of infants and pregnant women in their third trimester up through 6 weeks after cough onset.
3. The patient is no longer infectious and can return to school.

**For all households**: Administer Tdap to contacts 11 years or older who have not been previously vaccinated with Tdap, DTaP to contacts 2 months through 6 years who are not up-to-date, or refer for vaccination to a CDPH walk-in immunization clinic.
**Additional resources:**

• For complete guidance on pertussis treatment and PEP: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.[Recommended antimicrobial agents for the treatment and postexposure prophylaxis of pertussis: 2005 CDC guidelines. MMWR Recomm Rep. 2005;54(RR-14):1--16](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5414a1.htm).
• Clinical and laboratory guidance: [www.cdc.gov/pertussis.](https://www.cdc.gov/pertussis/index.html)",True,
