column7: Target Audience: This course is designed for Physicians, PAs, NPs and RNs who see patients with or who are at risk for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).
column9: Course Description: This course is an STD Update with a focus on Special Populations: STDs in pregnancy (congenital syphilis prevention); STDs in adolescents; STDs in transgender patients; STDs in men who have sex with men (MSM).
column11: Course Objectives: At the end of this course, participants should be able to:
column12: 1. Describe current approaches to preventing congenital syphilis.
column13: 2. Discuss STD morbidity and prevention strategies in adolescents.
column14: 3. Describe new developments in STD care for transgender persons.
column15: 4. Understand epidemiology of STD in men who have sex with men.
column18: ","**STD Update Webinar: Focus on Special Populations Dec 6, 2018**

column1: Please see attached flyer for course description and registration details. (cost $25.00)
PRESENTED BY THE ST. LOUIS STD/HIV PREVENTION TRAINING CENTER at WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
++Target Audience:++This course is designed for Physicians, PAs, NPs and RNs who see patients with or who are at risk for sexually transmitted diseases (STDs).

++Course Description++: This course is an STD Update with a focus on Special Populations: STDs in pregnancy (congenital syphilis prevention); STDs in adolescents; STDs in transgender patients; STDs in men who have sex with men (MSM).
++Course Objectives++: At the end of this course, participants should be able to:
1. Describe current approaches to preventing congenital syphilis.
2. Discuss STD morbidity and prevention strategies in adolescents.
3. Describe new developments in STD care for transgender persons.
4. Understand epidemiology of STD in men who have sex with men.
Registration: <https://courses.nnptc.org/registration.html?id=2390>",True,

column1: VFC News Bulletin -- October 30, 2018
PLEASE READ AND SHARE WITH ALL STAFF IN YOUR OFFICE!
New Regulation on ""Public Charge"" -- Comments Needed!

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) recently proposed a new regulation on ""public charge"" that could harm immigrant families' willingness to access nutrition support, housing assistance and health care. The American Academy of Pediatrics (APP) released a [news article](http://www.aappublications.org/news/2018/10/16/washington101618) about the proposal and AAPs advocacy efforts.",True,

IDPH Health Advisory:  Candida auris public health reporting in Illinois,2018-10-30T15:31:42.000,46651579,Public Health Recommendations and Evaluations,,Low,IDPH Health Advisory:  Candida auris public health reporting in Illinois,"<div>
column2: Candida auris (C. auris) is a yeast of public health concern due to its ability to cause outbreaks in health care settings, and because it is often multidrug-resistant (i.e., cannot be treated by many of the common types of antifungal medications). The first case of C. auris was reported in Illinois in May 2016. As of October 17, 2018, 84 clinical cases have been reported, and 305 cases have been identified as colonized through screening efforts. More information on C. auris can be found at the IDPH website.
column6: Given the increasing case numbers of this pathogen of public health significance, C. auris is a reportable disease under the Control of Communicable Diseases Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 690.565, Outbreaks of Public Health Significance). All cases identified via routine clinical care or for screening purposes should be reported to your local health department via phone or email within seven days. A list of local health department contacts can be found at this link.
column10: <div>
column12: Local health departments are asked to contact IDPH regarding case identification at dph.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov. Also, in accordance with Section 200(d)(4) of the CD Code, to prevent the spread of an infectious disease, IDPH or local health departments may share confidential information contained in surveillance reports and other individually identifiable health information with health care facilities and health care providers for treatment, prevention and control purposes (Control of Communicable Diseases Code, 77 Ill. Adm. Code 690.200(d)(4)). Confidential information will only be shared with other health care providers or facilities for the purposes of treatment, prevention, and response and this information will be shared in a manner that protects confidentiality of all protected health information.
column16: <div>
column21: Contact the Chicago Department of Public Health at cdphhaiar@cityofchicago.org  or Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 (Fax: 312-746-4683).
column22: ","Candida auris (C. auris) is a yeast of public health concern due to its ability to cause outbreaks in health care settings, and because it is often multidrug-resistant (i.e., cannot be treated by many of the common types of antifungal medications). The first case of C. auris was reported in Illinois in May 2016. As of October 17, 2018, 84 clinical cases have been reported, and 305 cases have been identified as colonized through screening efforts. More information on C. auris can be found at the [IDPH website.](http://www.dph.illinois.gov/topics-services/diseases-and-conditions/infectious-diseases/candida-auris)

Code 690.565, Outbreaks of Public Health Significance). All cases identified via routine clinical care or for screening purposes should be reported to your local health department via phone or email within seven days. A list of local health department contacts can be found at this[link](http://www.idph.state.il.us/LHDMap/HealthRegions.aspx).

Local health departments are asked to contact IDPH regarding case identification at dph.XDRORegistry@illinois.gov. Also, in accordance with Section 200(d)(4) of the CD Code, to prevent the spread of an infectious disease, IDPH or local health departments may share confidential information contained in surveillance reports and other individually identifiable health information with health care facilities and health care providers for treatment, prevention and control purposes (Control of Communicable Diseases Code, 77 Ill. Adm. Code 690.200(d)(4)). Confidential information will only be shared with other health care providers or facilities for the purposes of treatment, prevention, and response and this information will be shared in a manner that protects confidentiality of all protected health information.
Contact the Chicago Department of Public Health at [cdphhaiar@cityofchicago.org](mailto:cdphhaiar@cityofchicago.org){#LPlnk583640} or Massimo Pacilli at 312-746-6225 (Fax: 312-746-4683).",True,

For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,

Provider Reporting REQs and Authority of Public Hlth Personnel to Investigate Viral Hepatitis Cases,2018-10-24T20:54:08.000,46651178,Infectious Disease,,Low,Reminder Regarding Provider Reporting Requirements and Authority of Public Health Personnel to Investigate Viral Hepatitis Cases,"
column2: The purpose of this memo is to remind medical providers, infection preventionists, laboratories and other reporting entities of reporting and investigation requirements for viral Hepatitis, including Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and Hepatitis D.
column4: All reportable communicable diseases are reportable as soon as possible, but within 24 hours for hepatitis A and within seven days for hepatitis B, C and D. For a complete list of reportable conditions, visit the IDPH Infectious Disease Reporting page. Timely reporting of communicable diseases and collection of relevant information during investigations is of fundamental importance to identify outbreaks, prevent secondary transmission, evaluate the effectiveness of control measures, and monitor trends.
column5: Providers in Chicago can report these and all reportable diseases by calling the Chicago Department of Public Health at 312-743-9000.
column6:
Please see the attachment for full details.

","The purpose of this memo is to remind medical providers, infection preventionists, laboratories and other reporting entities of reporting and investigation requirements for viral Hepatitis, including Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C and Hepatitis D.

column1: All reportable communicable diseases are reportable as soon as possible, but within 24 hours for hepatitis A and within seven days for hepatitis B, C and D. For a complete list of reportable conditions, visit the [IDPH Infectious Disease Reporting page](http://dph.illinois.gov/topics-services/diseases-and-conditions/infectious-diseases/infectious-disease-reporting). **Timely reporting of communicable diseases and collection of relevant information during investigations is of fundamental importance to identify outbreaks, prevent secondary transmission, evaluate the effectiveness of control measures, and monitor trends**.
Providers in Chicago can report these and all reportable diseases by calling the Chicago Department of Public Health at 312-743-9000.

Weekly Chicago Flu Update Week 41,2018-10-19T20:15:51.000,46650786,Influenza,,Low,Weekly Flu Update Week 41,"
column2: The Chicago Flu Update for Week 41 has been published. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a schedule of City of Chicago influenza vaccination clinics is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to www.chicagoflushots.org.
column3: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is low.
column4: For the week of October 7-13, 2018, no influenzaassociated ICU hospitalizations were reported. Since September 30, 2018, two influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported; both were positive for influenza A (not subtyped).
column5: Since September 30, 2018, 1 of 1,050 (<1%) specimens tested for influenza has been positive for influenza A (unknown subtype [subtyping not performed or not all subtypes tested]).
column6: The first influenza-associated pediatric death reported in the U.S. this season occurred in Florida and was positive for influenza B. Influenza B virus co-circulates with influenza A at low levels during the first half of the influenza season. However, activity increases towards the second half of the season becoming the predominant circulating virus during that time.
column7: The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
column8:
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza.

","The Chicago Flu Update for Week 41 has been published. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a schedule of City of Chicago influenza vaccination clinics is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](https://chicagoflushots.org/).

column1: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is low.

For the week of October 7-13, 2018, no influenzaassociated ICU hospitalizations were reported. Since September 30, 2018, two influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported; both were positive for influenza A (not subtyped).
Since September 30, 2018, 1 of 1,050 (\<1%) specimens tested for influenza has been positive for influenza A (unknown subtype \[subtyping not performed or not all subtypes tested\]).

The first influenza-associated pediatric death reported in the U.S. this season occurred in Florida and was positive for influenza B. Influenza B virus co-circulates with influenza A at low levels during the first half of the influenza season. However, activity increases towards the second half of the season becoming the predominant circulating virus during that time.
The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,

Weekly Chicago Flu Update Week 40,2018-10-15T18:08:28.000,46650879,Public Health Recommendations and Evaluations,,Low,Weekly Flu Update Week 40,"
column2: The Chicago Flu Update for Week 40 has been published. This is the first Chicago Flu Update of the 2018-2019 influenza season. This report will be issued every Friday until May 2019. The Illinois Department of Public Health recently issued Influenza Testing and Reporting Guidance which outlines influenza testing recommendations and reporting requirements. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a schedule of City of Chicago influenza vaccination clinics is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to www.chicagoflushots.org.
column3: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is low.
column4: For the week of September 30-October 6, 2018, two influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported; both were positive for influenza A (not subtyped).
column5: Last season (2017-2018) recorded the highest number of ICU hospitalizations since the 2009 pandemic and alone accounted for nearly 30% of all reported cases since 2010-2011. The 2017-2018 season was an influenza A (H3N2) predominant season and the highest rate of ICU hospitalizations were among those sixty-five years of age and older, which is similar to previous seasons.
column6: Last season also recorded the highest number of deaths (38) reported among ICU hospitalizations since 2010- 2011. The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
column7:
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza.

","The Chicago Flu Update for Week 40 has been published. This is the first Chicago Flu Update of the 2018-2019 influenza season. This report will be issued every Friday until May 2019. The Illinois Department of Public Health recently issued Influenza Testing and Reporting Guidance which outlines influenza testing recommendations and reporting requirements. Vaccination is the best way to protect against influenza infection and all Chicagoans six months and older are encouraged to get vaccinated. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability. For those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the influenza vaccine, a schedule of City of Chicago influenza vaccination clinics is available on the city website and by calling 311. To locate the closest City of Chicago clinic or retail pharmacy, go to [www.chicagoflushots.org](http://www.chicagoflushots.org).

column1: Currently, the risk of influenza infection is low.
For the week of September 30-October 6, 2018, two influenza-associated ICU hospitalizations were reported; both were positive for influenza A (not subtyped).

Last season (2017-2018) recorded the highest number of ICU hospitalizations since the 2009 pandemic and alone accounted for nearly 30% of all reported cases since 2010-2011. The 2017-2018 season was an influenza A (H3N2) predominant season and the highest rate of ICU hospitalizations were among those sixty-five years of age and older, which is similar to previous seasons.

Last season also recorded the highest number of deaths (38) reported among ICU hospitalizations since 2010- 2011. The Chicago Department of Public Health recently issued guidance on reporting influenza associated ICU hospitalizations stressing the importance of prompt and complete reporting.
For questions on influenza reporting requirements please contact (312) 746-5911. Current and prior Chicago Flu Updates can be found at: <https://www.chicagohan.org/influenza.org/influenza>.",True,

Laboratory Testing Update for Zika, Dengue, Chikungunya and Other Arboviral Agents,2018-10-12T17:16:47.000,46650783,Laboratory Information,,Low,"Laboratory Testing Update for Zika, Dengue, Chikungunya and Other Arboviral Agents","<div>
column2: IDPH has distributed the following updated information in regards to available testing for arboviral pathogens at the IDPH Chicago Laboratory and recommendations for testing at commercial laboratories:
column6: Testing for Zika, Chikungunya and Dengue at the IDPH Chicago Laboratory will continue for those who meet criteria for testing as per CDC guidance and are uninsured or underinsured.
column9: Testing for California Encephalitis at the IDPH Chicago Laboratory will be discontinued
column10: <li>
column15: Commercial laboratories are requested to hold positive arboviral specimens for 30 days
column18: Attached is an IDPH memo with more information on IDPH laboratory arboviral testing updates.
column20: Additional information on Zika testing is available on our HAN page. Providers may submit request for Zika virus testing during normal business hours, Monday through Friday (excluding holidays) via fax at 312-746-4683.
column21: ","IDPH has distributed the following updated information in regards to available testing for arboviral pathogens at the IDPH Chicago Laboratory and recommendations for testing at commercial laboratories:

column1: * Testing for Zika, Chikungunya and Dengue at the IDPH Chicago Laboratory will continue for those who meet criteria for testing as per CDC guidance and are uninsured or underinsured.
* Testing for California Encephalitis at the IDPH Chicago Laboratory will be discontinued
* Confirming WNV infection testing considerations
* Commercial laboratories are requested to hold positive arboviral specimens for 30 days
Attached is an IDPH memo with more information on IDPH laboratory arboviral testing updates.

Additional information on Zika testing is available on our [HAN page](https://www.chicagohan.org/zika). Providers may submit request for Zika virus testing during normal business hours, Monday through Friday (excluding holidays) via fax at 312-746-4683.",True,
